# Titolo: La Traduzione come Arte

## Introduzione

La traduzione è un'arte raffinata che richiede non solo una profonda conoscenza delle lingue, ma anche una sensibilità culturale e una maestria linguistica. In questo viaggio attraverso le parole, ci immergiamo nell'affascinante mondo della traduzione italiana-inglese, esplorando le sfumature e le sfide che esso presenta.

## La Sfida della Traduzione

Tradurre non è semplicemente sostituire parole da una lingua all'altra. È un processo complesso che coinvolge la comprensione del contesto, la cattura dell'essenza del testo originale e la sua riproduzione in una nuova lingua con fedeltà e grazia. L'italiano, con la sua ricchezza di espressioni idiomatiche e la sua musicalità, presenta sfide uniche per il traduttore.

## Adattare e Preservare

L'obiettivo principale di un traduttore è di adattare il testo alla nuova lingua, preservando al contempo il suo significato e il suo impatto originale. Questo richiede una scelta attenta delle parole, una comprensione delle strutture grammaticali e una sensibilità per le differenze culturali. La traduzione deve fluire naturalmente, come se fosse stata scritta nella lingua di destinazione fin dall'inizio.

## Esplorare le Sfumature

La lingua italiana è nota per le sue sfumature e sottigliezze. Espressioni come "fare una passeggiata" (che implica un'azione rilassata) e "andare a spasso" (che suggerisce un movimento più casuale) richiedono una traduzione attenta per catturare la sfumatura di significato. Il traduttore deve essere un artista, dipingendo con parole per evocare la stessa atmosfera e emozioni del testo originale.

## Conclusione

La traduzione italiana-inglese è un'arte che richiede dedizione, competenza e una profonda comprensione di entrambe le culture. È un processo creativo che trasforma le parole, mantenendo intatta la loro essenza. Attraverso questa pratica, i traduttori diventano ponti tra culture, facilitando la comunicazione e arricchendo la nostra comprensione del mondo.

The crisis in the automotive sector has morphed into a crisis encompassing an entire industry, its supply chain, related sectors, commercial networks, and consequently, services. It presents dramatic prospects from an employment perspective.

I believe that even the dramatic drop in these latest enrollments for this month, which is said to be thirty-three percent less, twenty percent less in some Member States, and so on, demonstrates that this is not a crisis of a technologically obsolete sector. It does not originate within the sector itself or within this or that company due to managerial errors.
This is a systemic crisis and as such it must be urgently and decisively addressed by the European institutions themselves.
Some remedies seem to be identified, but it is important how to implement them, with what resources, and with what innovation prospects.
Certainly, the demand must be supported; consumption is the only driver of recovery.

But, while this response of supporting consumption is being implemented as a medium-term measure, I believe we must emphasize the immediate need for credit support to resume production, pay for materials, and sustain employment, even in the face of declining orders and demand.
Thus the credit sector, but as we were saying, the way in which it is done is important.

As the sponsor of the inquiry, I emphasize that lowering the quality of our productions, the result of centuries of traditions and research, of significant investments, and of passion,

and attention to detail is not the response we need, especially in a time of economic crisis like this one, where the average consumer is undoubtedly more focused on price than on any writing on the label.

To counterbalance this decision, it would be sufficient to find a name for the new product and inform consumers about the existence of two different types of rosé, the different quality of the products, and the importance of recognizing the work and efforts of professionals in the sector.

Mr. President, allow me first of all to greet the President of the DTP party, Mr. Ahmed Turk, who is here with us in the gallery and who is following the debate.
Dear Ahmed, know that we stand in solidarity with you, supporting the democratic struggle your party leads in Turkey for the recognition of the fundamental rights of the Kurdish people.
We recognize the DTP as an indispensable tool for the promotion of democracy in Turkey, and for this reason, we firmly condemn the police operations that...
Prime Minister Erdogan has issued orders against you, imprisoning all three vice presidents of the DTP, along with over three hundred activists and sympathizers.
The victory of the DTP in the recent local elections demonstrates that the DTP party enjoys strong democratic popular support.

The European Parliament, in its resolutions, has called on Prime Minister Erdogan to engage in direct discussions with the DTP, but his response has been more repression, more police, more authoritarianism, and more imprisonment.

Everyone is aware that my parliamentary group and the Left in Europe have until now supported the process of Turkey's accession to the European Union, while also backing the reform process in that country.

However, I believe that in these last two years and especially in recent months, Erdogan has shown another face—that of a leader compromised with the worst elements of the Turkish army who simply want to massacre the Kurds.
The reform process is practically dead, prisons are filling up with Kurds, it is Erdogan himself who is closing any perspective of Turkey's accession.
It is yours, and yours alone, is the responsibility for what is happening in Euro-Turkish relations and the growing perplexity of European public opinion towards Turkey.

I want to send a very strong political message to Erdogan: either he makes the search for a political and negotiated solution to the Kurdish issue a priority, which, let it be clear, goes through direct negotiations with the DTP, or we will be the ones to call for the suspension of the accession negotiations with the European Union.

The path of Turkey's accession to the Union goes through Diyarbakir and the DTP, otherwise it will be us, those who have supported the accession process here, who will call for a reflection period that risks being definitive.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I would like to thank the Council for sharing the principles and, above all, if you allow me, Commissioner Barro, with whom I had a very fruitful dialogue. This was extremely useful for the work we then presented in the House.

I would like to express my heartfelt thanks to the colleagues who worked on this report, providing me with ideas and, of course, bringing all their expertise, first and foremost to my colleague Demetriou, Baroness Latford, and the excellent Chairman Depree.

I would argue that what Demetrich, Latford, and Depree say is precisely the most important thing, the challenge for the European Union, because achieving a unified European judicial culture is the goal.
Of course, waging a serious battle on what Depree says about the independence of justice, guarantees, and addressing the disparities of various judicial systems are the challenges ahead.
But I believe that the work we have done allows us to be optimistic.
I would like to address the Honorable Romagnoli and say that, from my perspective, which I believe should also be his, there is undoubtedly a prevailing pessimism regarding Italy's rational approach.

The optimism of the will and the work that you too, Honorable Romagnoli, have done, and the contribution you have given to the report, means that all together we can build the European Union, and the European Union is a reality also for us Italians.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, it seems that the thousands of deaths we have seen so far due to asbestos, the tens of thousands of deaths we have witnessed due to asbestos,

of people at risk of dying in the coming years due to past exposure to asbestos, we know that the latency period can reach fifteen and even twenty years, which are absolutely insignificant in this context.

It seems that the Eternit process begun in Turin regarding what happened in Casale Monferrato is not continuing, where there is not a single family that has not experienced a bereavement within its ranks.
Asbestos should have been effectively banned by Member States through the application of the 1999 directive.

States should have protected exposed workers with all possible precautions, implementing the 2003 directive, closing facilities, remediating contaminated sites, and compensating victims and affected populations.
This did not happen everywhere.
Little or nothing has been done.
I have already spoken about the Turin trial, where Swiss and Belgian owners are defendants.
Everyone knew that little was done, and it is primarily the industry that shirks its responsibilities, acting within the gaps of public authority inertia.
Examples of inertia can be seen, for instance, in Italy, in Brioni where asbestos has not been removed, in Porto Margherita, and in Cengio, where deaths are still being counted.
Today, industry is asking the Commission to tolerate a further derogation already granted for a limited time by the REACH Regulation in 2006 for chrysotile asbestos fibers.

It is true that they have a limited application to low-voltage electrolysis plants and only in a few facilities, but where industry leaders claim that any alternative substitute is impossible, lest it lead to the closure of the plants.

A threat, but alternatives to this process have been found in Sweden, employing technologies in asbestos-free membrane replacement for low voltage, and a similar solution has also been adopted for hydrogen production.
Why in some states yes and in others no?
For why, as in the long battle for the ban on PCBs, there have been countless omissions and hesitations to act, even endorsed by the Directorate-General for Enterprise of the European Commission.
Even in this case, a poor example has been set.
The 1999 directive on the prohibition of asbestos required that the review of such authorization be preceded by an opinion from the scientific committee on toxicity, which was never produced.
This is how the Commission respects the directives.
Not to mention the union, which claims it was not even consulted.
The European Parliament makes its own effort to catch up with others in terms of compliance.

This resolution calls on the Commission to fill, by 2009, a legislative gap regarding the banning of second-hand asbestos-containing products, such as roofing materials, aircraft parts, and other items, which should be definitively disposed of.
Specific dates are set once again for a strategy to ban all types of asbestos by 2015, but these were already objectives outlined in 1999.
Ten years have passed and people have continued to die.
The GUE had claimed among the first initiatives of this legislative term the establishment of a community compensation fund for victims, and ad hoc funds for decontamination.
The request was specific to the Commission, which today, however, yields to the will of multinational corporations.
It is necessary, instead, to move on to concrete actions and commitments.
Only when these start from the very requests of this resolution, only then can we be understanding.
Today, this will is not evident, therefore we vote against the granting of the derogation.

Thank you, Mr. President, and I would like to convey to President Buzek the pride that fills me at this moment in belonging to an important institution such as the European Parliament, which you preside over.

I believe that the sacrifices made over the past twenty years in your country, and which today are represented by those twelve countries previously mentioned in this Assembly, lend strength to Europe.
However, I also wish to convey my concern after listening to your program as part of your speech, which should, and I hope will, strengthen this Parliament.
I hope that what you have announced will come to pass.

I hope that the next President of the European Commission, certainly President Barroso, will want to listen to her for the strong words she has spoken, to ensure that this Parliament provides answers to more than...

550 million citizens who voted for us in this Europe, who wanted and want and demand from this Parliament, from all of us, the answers that Europe has certainly tried to provide but has not fully succeeded in giving.
Upon this endeavor of yours, I set my hopes in motion and I am certain that with you we will manage to attain the certainties that you yourself have promised us.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, honorable colleagues, it is not my intention, nor that of my group which has supported and requested this debate, to transfer the tribal politics of Italian internal affairs to a European level.

The issue of freedom of information concerns all of us and the European Union, which can and must regulate the matter at the community level in order to counter political and economic pressures and to guarantee genuine pluralism in information.

The Italian anomaly, where the Prime Minister is also the owner of some of the most important private networks, lies precisely in the existence of a dangerous entanglement between media, political, and economic powers.

It is precisely for this reason that we are calling for European regulatory intervention, an intervention that, far from being an act of anti-Italian sentiment, aims to protect media pluralism by preventing concentrations of ownership and conflicts of interest.

For this reason, today we call on the Commission to act as soon as possible, as this Parliament has also requested in the past, to equip the European Union with common rules to protect the freedom of information for all European citizens.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I am aware that on September 30th, the Commission presented a study on media pluralism indices in the Member States.
But in 2008, a report by rapporteur Marianne Micco was adopted, in which the European Commission and the Member States were urged to protect, I quote verbatim, the multiplicity of...
of opinions in the media, to defend the pluralism of information, to ensure that all European Union citizens have equal access to free and diverse media.

Even earlier, in 2004, a report by Bogert Quack, on the risks of violations in the European Union of freedom of expression and information, was adopted in Parliament. This report called on the Commission to present a communication on guaranteeing media pluralism in all Member States.
To date, the Commission has not yet provided clear responses to the Parliament's requests.

You will notice, Commissioner, that I have not mentioned my country or my Prime Minister, but as a European citizen, I ask you here what the Commission intends to do at European level to ensure that media pluralism is guaranteed in all Member States.
Thank you. Given that the discussion about the vote that took place yesterday in the Environment Committee has been raised several times,
I would like it to be evident that not everything can be reduced to a single extremist ideological position.

We have heard many positions from our colleagues, which are very diverse, much more nuanced, much more common-sensical, and therefore, being more in line with reality, I believe they are better equipped to provide real answers.
Science as a totem does not exist, and when the mistake of identifying a problem in such an ideological way has been made, it has not provided answers but has led to further issues.
disasters, and Europe should be a master in this field and not repeat the same mistakes, even if they are dressed up differently and given labels that appear to be much more friendly.
I must recall that the same emission trading directive specifically stipulates that the European Union's virtuous path is to be evaluated by the Commission based on the outcomes of the conference.
We must go to the conference with certainly strong positions, with clear ideas, but absolutely seeking to equitably divide the efforts.
Efforts among all industrialized countries, firstly, which must adopt equivalent emission reduction targets, but also without forgetting what colleague Grostet aptly recalled,
Among developing countries, we must make distinctions. There are truly developing countries, and then there are those that have now emerged as economies, such as India, China, and Brazil.
These are countries that cannot help but assume their own commitments as well.

On the contrary, I strongly urge that if balance is not achieved in Copenhagen, the European Union must continue to ensure the allocation of free allowances to sectors at risk under Directive 2387/EC.

These are fundamental points. We want the Kyoto Protocol itself to retain its environmental significance, and above all, we want to prevent the creation of a financial bubble at the expense of our European businesses.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the first reason why this is very important is the research topic, which concerns the fight against neurodegenerative diseases. The second reason is the method of joint programming in research.
We would have obviously preferred, and this has been stated and is the subject of our inquiry, a more direct involvement of the Parliament in the pilot project.

If we must now proceed without pausing, we nonetheless request assurances that our opinion will be taken into consideration in the reception of the Competitiveness Council's conclusions, and that a more certain legal basis for full parliamentary involvement and greater ownership of this research matter be clarified for the future.

Now we must intervene with appropriate means and resources to prevent and eradicate a scourge as widespread as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and other diseases that are destined to increase with the aging of the population.
We call for a focus on large-scale and wide-ranging studies, aimed at both diagnosis and the identification of treatments.

Fundamental seem to be the researches on biomarkers, on early diagnosis methods based on a multidisciplinary approach, the establishment of extensive databases, the search for curative drugs and models of care and appropriate services.

I feel compelled to make a single point in this context: neither the subjectivity of patients, too often excluded in this type of disease, nor the involvement of patient and relative associations should be overlooked.
From a methodological standpoint, we believe joint research projects to be highly significant as they address a fundamental need: the concentration of efforts and resources.
to overcome those fragmentations, those duplications, and thus create a critical mass sufficient to yield adequate outcomes for this type of research.

If we consider that in other areas of the world, joint public and private efforts result in investments of tens of millions of euros, we realize how much remains to be done and how much we must do, converging on projects.

shared, on strategic lines and programs agreed upon between States and Europe, and on common programs between public and private entities, without neglecting that international framework that connects us to the major scientific realities at the international level.
What are the novelties of the Stockholm program compared to the Hague program? A fair balance between rights and security, and legal protection in both criminal and civil fields.

Safety is a right: not to be assaulted in one's workplace, to walk the streets without risking one's life, not to be subjected to violence because one is a woman, not to be exposed to acts of terrorism.
States and Europe must ensure security.
But a security measure that weakens guarantees of freedom is a measure that undermines the certainty of law and is thus a source of insecurity and barbarity.
Guantanamo.
Europe is the homeland of rights.
The Stockholm Program defines them in great detail.

Today, a fair balance between the discipline of crime suppression on the one hand and the daily life of citizens, their family, social, economic, work, and study relationships, all regulated by civil law and civil justice.
This is the Europe of the citizen.
and it will be built within the States and the Community institutions.
European society is more united, and mobility is more intense than one might think.
Tameability is now a right.
The borders between states are not impenetrable walls, they are nets through which society filters every day.
Stockholm forms the institutional framework for judicial cooperation and mutual recognition, towards a European justice, built upon national justice.
and that of the community, a European right, national and community, a European citizen, a European judge, the national one and the community one.

European rules are dictated by community regulations and the jurisprudence of the European courts, but also stem from the behaviors of workers, businesses, students, national magistrates, and European networks among justice professionals.
Therefore, it is this bottom-up process that the Stockholm Programme aims to support.
The Parliament has made a great effort with this resolution, which I hope will be supported here by a broad, unanimous vote, for which we have worked intensively.
the Council kindly take note of this.
Lisbon is not yet in force, but it is there, very much present.
Let the Council be ambitious, Madam/Sir Minister, make the most of what we have developed here and the wealth of insights that emerge from it.
In the Budgetary Control Committee, I must acknowledge the very important work carried out by the Committee, the excellent work of the rapporteur, and I must also mention the political unity.

This is because from the very beginning we have wanted to send a very clear message: we intend to work with great rigor to ensure transparency, correctness, and legality in the management of public funds and, consequently, in the verification of budgets.
Very significant steps have been taken with the Council, which initially did not want to respond.
I personally acknowledge this to the Swedish Presidency, which has always sought to demonstrate its commitment to transparency and fairness.
So we expect further progress from this perspective because it is obviously absolutely unacceptable, especially with the entry into force of the treaty.
Lisbon, that the Parliament should not have information and news precisely to verify the budget and public funds in the interest not only of the European Union but also of all the citizens of Europe.
Honorable President, we were in Ramallah when the news arrived that Europe had adopted a new decision on the peace process in the Middle East.
We have witnessed the smile of hope on the faces of the Palestinian representatives.
These were intense days of emotions and sufferings, etched onto the faces of children clinging to the window grates of their homes, on Hebron Street, the ghost road that no Palestinian can cross.

The suffering of an eighty-five-year-old woman evicted from her home, forced to sleep in the cold in a tent pitched in the garden of what had been her house, the suffering etched on the faces of those Palestinians who, with European funding, had built a farm later destroyed by Israeli soldiers.
Israel has the right to be an independent state, but Palestinians also have the right to have a homeland, a state, and a passport.
The decision by the Council of Europe represents a significant step forward, but action must be taken immediately.
The conflict between Israel and Palestine is the tip of the iceberg of a larger conflict.
On the final day of the visit, the Israeli authorities prevented us, the European Parliament delegation, from visiting the Gaza Strip.
I believe that on this matter, the High Representative, Baroness Ashton, should intervene to voice the protest of democratic Europe.

I would like to thank President De Rossa, who led the delegation, and all its other members. During our stay in Palestine, the Palestinians who are vulnerable were able to see and hear the face and the words of a Europe that defends rights and wants and must do more.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the European Union is committed to the fight against terrorism in all its dimensions.

When discussing the fight against terrorist offenses, it is essential to ensure that fundamental rights are fully respected and that the measures adopted to combat terrorism are appropriate and effective.

The rights of the defense and fundamental procedural guarantees must therefore be fully respected by the Union's institutions, even when they draw up lists of people and identities, in this case linked to certain individuals.

It is essential that Al Qaeda operatives are subject to restrictive measures, and it is equally essential that these measures are subject to adequate democratic and parliamentary scrutiny, as the Lisbon Treaty rightly prescribes.

It is therefore evident that, as also stated by the Legal Service of the Parliament, any measure of this kind must follow the co-decision procedure, allowing representatives of European citizens to fully exercise their legislative and oversight role.
Mr. President, I would like to avoid continuing to list the reasons for our dissent with the Iranian government.
I would like to emphasize, since it was not mentioned here, one of the most serious facts regarding the violation of civil rights, which is the one perpetrated against young people.
Having signed the United Nations Treaty on the Rights of the Child, the Iranian government has nonetheless persisted in imposing capital punishment on minors.
I would like, after this debate, for Baroness Ashton to undertake to outline a common line for all of Europe and the entire European Parliament.
European Parliament on the developments in Iran and, on the other hand, that the interparliamentary commission with the Iranian government acknowledges that the course needs to be changed.

I participated with friends Scuria and Tattarella in the protest we had organized against the Commission, which, nevertheless, through an official statement, declared its intention to go to Iran. We had instead categorically requested that there be an opportunity to meet with the opposition and engage in dialogue with them.

I would like the Commission, from this moment onwards, to turn over a new leaf and establish relations of aid, support, and dialogue with the representatives of the opposition in exile, not least Ms. Miriam Raiavi, who represents this reality.
The European community should be doing this instead of imposing sanctions.

Colleagues, I wish to draw attention to the severity of deindustrialization situations facing several Sicilian industrial hubs, particularly the automotive sector in Termini Merese, Fiat group, and the petrochemical plant in Gela, Eni group.
Immersed and damaged by competition from the low-wage system within certain eurozone countries, it freezes out Asian competition.
In light of the severe deindustrialization processes unfolding across vast regions of the Union, I believe it is high time to reconsider the policy of non-intervention.
intervention so far adopted by the European Commission and to start implementing a package of measures to support relevant and strategic European industries.
This exhortation is primarily addressed to the European Commission and Commissioner for Industry Tajani.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the issue of good fiscal governance, while always having been of great importance, has gained even greater relevance and urgency in the aftermath of the major economic and financial crisis of two years ago.
International summits, such as the G20 and European gatherings, have discussed and continue to debate these issues, especially when addressing the fight against tax evasion and offshore tax havens.
All this is important, it is a sign of commitment and determination, but one must not delude oneself that an announcement is enough.
A serious and consistent policy is needed.
many problems remain.
It is still far too easy to buy or set up a shell company to evade taxes.
A simple browse on the internet reveals thousands of websites offering companies for sale, even in European Union countries.
Often, it is sufficient to send an email with an attached scanned copy of the passport to be able to open a company.
The practice of creating fictitious legal entities to evade taxation must be put to an end.
This report that I am presenting is based on the European Commission's communication on good fiscal governance of April 28, 2009.
The report is aimed at putting forward concrete proposals and calls for a strong commitment from the European Commission and the Council to implement these proposals.
The fight against tax havens, tax evasion, and illicit capital flight must be considered a priority of the European Union.
From here stems the principle of good governance, based on transparency, information exchange, cross-border cooperation, and fair tax competition.
The point is that there is a growing need for fiscal cooperation and collaboration within the European Union.
The overall goal we should aim for is to achieve automatic information exchange on a global and multilateral scale, starting, of course, from the European Union.
As already stated by colleague Alvarez, we must completely abolish bank secrecy in European Union countries and put an end, without further delay, to the derogation regime.
temporary measure authorizing the application of a withholding tax at source, often evaded or underestimated, in lieu of information exchange.
I do not intend to elaborate on the specific proposals contained in the report.
I emphasize that we still need, in particular, to: expand the scope of the 2003 Savings Directive, combat VAT fraud, and establish a public register of the Union.
that takes into account individuals or businesses that have established companies or opened accounts in tax havens.

from the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base. It is also necessary for the European Union to speak with one voice internationally, to advocate for the improvement of OECD regulations to achieve automatic exchange of information instead of exchange on request.

Commissioner Kovacs, having heard the other reports, we need a strong commitment from the Commission. At this moment, as the new Commission takes office, we need these priorities to be emphasized during the handover process.
We will hold the Council and the European Commission to account for the work.
As the European Parliament, I would like to thank my colleagues and especially the Shadow Rapporteurs for their contribution to this work, which I hope will be approved by the Parliament.

I must admit that when we talk about counter-terrorism, focusing solely on intelligence and technology, I always get the impression that we insist on addressing the issue inadequately, as if we wanted to cure a disease by focusing only on its symptoms and not its causes.
Is it not high time to tackle the problem of terrorism, by addressing the core of the issue, rather than merely focusing on its outward phenomenology?

Addressing the core of the issue means, for instance, acknowledging that terrorism is also a direct manifestation of the inability or unwillingness of ethnic groups to integrate into the European cultural fabric.
I wonder and ask this Parliament: Do we want to discuss terrorism?
Let this Parliament then have the courage to politically address a debate on the degree of integration of Muslims in Europe and their willingness to share Western values, rights, and freedoms.
In this regard, I have submitted a question to the Commission on the full-face veil to encourage this Assembly to openly confront the issue.
It appears that there is no intention to address the topic.
I wonder, and I ask you, honorable colleagues from all political groups, if not on these issues, on what other topics should the political arena of the peoples of Europe pronounce itself?
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, concluding the negotiation with Croatia by 2010 is an achievable goal, and the Svoboda report aptly highlights the progress made and the steps still to be taken.
Now it is the justice sector that still requires significant reforms.
It is not enough, in fact, to complete the necessary systemic reforms, enact new laws, and cooperate as required with the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia.
I insist on the need to create a genuine legal culture and mindset in line with European standards.

The independence of the judiciary becomes crucial, a central issue, along with the training, recruitment, and careers of judges. This includes the absence of various types of influence exerted by the government on judges.
I appeal to the Commission to consider the necessity of decisive measures in this regard during the final phase of the negotiation.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, Croatia's accession to the European Union strengthens the consolidation of a European identity, capable of expressing the common values of the new Europe, without eclipsing, but rather integrating the specific characteristics of its many facets.

The Republic of Croatia has made commendable efforts in aligning itself with the required parameters, particularly in combating organized crime through new anti-mafia measures. However, it needs to make further efforts, especially in the judicial sector, before the 2010 negotiations can be concluded.

Further steps can be taken by the institutions of the Republic of Croatia to align with the provisions of the first protocol of the European Convention on Human Rights, signed in Paris in 1952, by considering the restitution of nationalized property to its legitimate owners.
Mr. President, once again recently in Italy there has been an environmental disaster in the Lambro River and the Po River.
Recently, the Court of Justice in Luxembourg has convicted Italy for the danger posed to public health due to illegal waste disposal and for failing to control waste collection in rural areas.
And news of recent days of the increase in leukemias in Taranto through ILVA, as well as asbestos disposal in schools in Crotone, as well as dioxin in Campania.
It is an ongoing environmental disaster.

I strongly request the Commission to clarify what actions it intends to take to bring the Italian government into line with the standards of European Union directives, with specific reference to the Court of Justice's ruling the other day.
justice, which has harshly condemned Italy, which failed to manage waste in Campania, the city of Naples was exposed to public ridicule for many weeks and months around the world.

This debate is not ritualistic, but aims to be very practical and to ask clear and precise questions about how many resources are needed, and where they will come from. I hope, and the Parliament hopes, that equally clear and precise answers will be provided today and in the upcoming Councils on 12 and 25 March.

We firmly wish to tell the Commission and the Council that the European Union, which has raised the flag of the fight against atmospheric emissions and the climate challenge before the world, today has a duty of consistency if it does not want to lose credibility.
You must do everything possible to ensure these goals are achieved.

We must be very well aware that talking about a low-emission economy means a sort of Copernican revolution for the productive system, it means changing many things, having clear priorities, political will, but above all, adequate resources and tools.
We also know that this Copernican revolution is essential if our productive system, European industry, is to remain competitive.
I mean that in many countries, in many research centers, in many universities, the intelligences are ready, the capabilities exist, the will is there; now it is a matter of igniting this engine.
Everyone must do it, said the Commissioner, said the Council, it must be done by the Member States, entrepreneurs, and private entities.
But I believe that the task is indispensable to bring together this complex partnership, which is also of the European Union.
To constructively address the employment issue, the three key words in community relation are: react, evolve, and protect.

React, that is, move away from the celebratory tones of Europropaganda, to concretely address the issues affecting EU citizens, ensuring a direct link between the world of education and the needs of the market and the territory, and improving young people's perception of manual professions.

to evolve, that is, to make the EU 2020 strategy a positive synthesis between the demands of businesses and those of workers, in favor of a labor market where the flexibility and security of contractual forms respond to the instability of market demand.

to protect, that is, to provide employment to those who have lost it, first and foremost among our own citizens. Member States must therefore assess immigration policies based on the actual need for immigration, and with twenty-three million unemployed, the possibility of suspending extracomunity immigration for a few years should be considered.
I see no other way to protect our work and our social system.
What is needed is practicality, courage, and decentralization.
President, this is an oral amendment to point 13, where it invites the Commission to assess, in the current situation, the possibility of providing verified humanitarian aid given the situation.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I would like to underscore once again the significance of the written declaration on corruption that I proposed along with four other members of parliament and which a majority of the European Parliament has endorsed, thereby committing the Council and the Commission to truly effective legislation on corruption.

I have returned, on behalf of the Budget Control Commission, from a visit to Greece, and certainly one of the reasons for Greece's structural crisis also depends on the waste of public funds, a situation that also occurs in Italy.

corroded by corruption, as is emerging these days, corruption that primarily circulates through the illegal management of public funds, the relationship between a part of the political sphere and a part of the entrepreneurs, and the organized white-collar criminality.

It is important that the European Parliament exert all its pressure on the Commission and the Member States, that Member States that do not comply are sanctioned, and that European institutions responsible for controlling corruption and combating organized crime are strengthened.
We are well aware that this difference is even more pronounced in the realm of autonomous activities.
Indeed, all too often, women are forced to sacrifice their professional ambitions in the name of assuming the role and the workload that stems from the absolute dedication to the family.

To solve this problem, I believe it is necessary to implement measures such as those contained in the directive we are discussing, but always keeping our eyes fixed on the guiding star of the family. Only this can give meaning and hope of success to these very measures.

Freeing women from the anguishing dilemma of choosing between the roles of mother, wife, and entrepreneur means lightening the burden of family responsibilities and addressing the concrete issues through positive and specific measures of family support.
Placing the family at the center is crucial; otherwise, any package of measures will be an inconsistent set of interventions, ultimately proving futile.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, Mr. Commissioner, today we find ourselves discussing organ transplantation, which undoubtedly represents one of the most positive aspects of progress in healthcare.
but on the other hand, it raises a whole series of issues regarding the rights of the donor and the patient that need to be addressed on ethical, social, legal, and economic levels.
It involves initiating a virtuous process to address the severe imbalance between the need for organs and the quantity available, while still respecting the principle of free and voluntary donation.
every form of commercialization and illegal trafficking, ensuring the quality and safety of organs intended for transplantation, with measures that can combine confidentiality with traceability.

It goes without saying that in a context of cross-border exchanges and significant differences between the transplant systems adopted in the various Member States, these objectives can only be achieved by promoting coordination and cooperation.
In this regard, I believe it would be highly important to establish a European database and adopt common quality and security standards.
We must be careful, however, not to introduce unnecessary forms of rigidity or create additional bureaucratic burdens that compromise what is currently being done correctly and effectively.
Here, it would be not only contrary to our goals, but also against our very objectives.
Mr. President, I thank the rapporteur for the excellent work done on the European Union's accession to the Convention on Human Rights, which has been approved by the European Commission.

represents a benefit for European citizens, as it will establish a new Court outside the European Union to ensure that the rights of European citizens are always respected by the European Union and its Member States.

By virtue of the principle of democracy, the European Union and its Member States must always have the right to defend themselves. For this reason, I believe it is fundamental that every nation adhering to the Convention should have a judge who can explain the context of each appeal.

It is important that the European Parliament has an informal body with the aim of coordinating the exchange of information between the Parliament and the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council, and it is important that the Parliament is also consulted and involved in the negotiation process.
I would also add that European citizens have the right to understand the mechanisms of this accession, as they have the right to know what their rights are.

Therefore, I deem it essential for the Council of Europe and the European Union to consider developing guidelines, with a clear explanation of all the effects and implications that accession will entail.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, one hundred and seventy measures in five years, figures that are too ambitious for a program lacking a true focus, especially on certain issues.
On migration, the program, beyond official documents, reveals an embarrassing weakness. What is the point of promising to strengthen bodies and agencies if there is then a lack of political strategy?

A truly useful strategy must be based on several key points: combating illegal immigration along the southern border, sharing the burden among all European states in addressing illegality, a policy of agreements with third countries, and above all, recognizing that immigration, in times of crisis, is not a resource.
From the Parliament's homepage, we read that more than twenty percent of young people in Europe are unemployed.
In a continent with twenty-five million unemployed, the commissioner for home affairs states that the issue of migration must be based on solidarity.

Instead, we need to think with concreteness and realism. Today, the priority is to provide jobs for our citizens; everything else is empty rhetoric that helps neither the integration of immigrants nor, even less, our own people.
President, I apologize, I would like to take this opportunity to urge the Presidency to intervene regarding the a.
that flights between Strasbourg and European capitals are direct and do not continue to cause inconvenience to those who have to take three or four flights to reach Strasbourg.
I kindly request your appropriate intervention.

The financial national challenges of these months and years, the new Lisbon Treaty with its new responsibilities, and the ambitious goal we have set for ourselves with Europe 2020, all demand the mobilization of substantial new financial resources.
The paradox we are witnessing in this discussion as well is that, at present, both the Commission and the Council appear silent, unable to make choices and determine decisions.
But we know that if we want to emerge from this difficult economic and social phase, if we want to tackle the major challenges of the environment, development, cohesion policy, and
In the coming years, for the sake of agriculture, we have the necessity to invest more in Europe and in the role of Europe, and thus in the essential function of Europe, that is, its budget.
For this reason, we must not fear to discuss, even in a time of financial constraints, the possibility of investing more in resources.
having the strength and ability to foster a debate and a discussion that addresses the issue of more resources, as well as the themes of greater quality and flexibility in their use.
And this is the challenge that lies ahead of us.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, as we know, the European Parliament is called upon to definitively express itself on food information to consumers.
It must be stated at the outset that this was an objectively arduous, lengthy, and contentious legislative process, which could not be shortened.

The aim is indeed to harmonize Community law on food through regulations that ensure transparent consumer information, thus preventing them from making confused or potentially harmful choices, even with regard to their health.

The report by Honorable Sommer, who should be acknowledged for her effort in synthesizing multiple needs, aims therefore to remedy the controversial and diverse information systems in place across the countries of the Union.

It is no coincidence that national regulations to this day differ in the designations of the nature of foods for sale, creating a system that varies from country to country, also fueling unfair competition to the detriment of potential consumers.
Thus, based on the proposal of the European Commission, an attempt has been made to give a new form to the existing legislation, involving food industries on one hand and consumers on the other.
Simultaneously, the regulation commits the European food industry to clarify the mandatory indications and the presentation of nutritional and nutritional values.

In a globalized market, the European Union could not exempt itself from adapting and innovating its legislation on food products to better protect the food trade as well, safeguarding it from increasingly invasive and cutthroat international competition.

It is not new to hear more frequent talk of the perversity of food products than of the standardization of names and labels that often do not meet dietary requirements, yet are still marketed as healthy foods for human consumption.

because, by interpreting national rights in a European key, it provides the conditions to resolve conflicts and regulate the daily lives of citizens.

real advantages are offered to address a range of problems that would otherwise remain unsolved.

knowledge in itself and should be encouraged to apply this knowledge to the new challenges of European law and culture, fostering predominantly virtual conditions for exchange rather than merely virtual ones.
