This is a new approach.
What we mean, however, is that if a European mindset is not formed among magistrates and lawyers, who thus offer their services to justice and to the citizens who demand it, we will not build Europe.
So this is not just an important document for European justice, it is an important charter for the entire development of European unity.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the proposal on the rights of bus passengers aims to improve and protect passengers, particularly those with disabilities or reduced mobility.
This is the first regulation on the rights of bus passengers and should provide guarantees for passengers, as is already the case in the rail and air sectors.
The position in the second reading aims to establish a series of rights for passengers who decide to travel by bus.

I agree with the approach of rapporteur Cancian, whom I thank for the excellent work done, and I believe that the scope of the regulation should be amended to exclude regional services when they are integrated with urban and suburban services.
It would be fair and necessary to ensure the rights of passengers in the event of accidents, cancellations, or delays at departure, as had already been decided by the Parliament in its first reading.

Equally important is the issue of information on passenger rights. In fact, it would be useful to provide passengers with information on connections with other modes of transport. This will also ensure dialogue between passenger transport services by bus and by rail.

As for people with disabilities and reduced mobility, it is necessary to ensure the highest level of protection. I would propose using the term 'within twenty-four hours' instead of 'within forty-eight hours' to request assistance, as well as stronger guarantees for compensation and replacement of the tools that ensure the mobility of people with disabilities in case of loss or damage.
Furthermore, taking into account the needs of passengers with reduced mobility, any architectural barriers should be removed and existing infrastructure improved to make it accessible.
This regulation aims to enhance the competitiveness of the bus sector, promote intermodality, but above all, to improve passenger travel conditions.
Mr. President, I thank Rapporteur Sterks who has done an excellent job on this report, which addresses how to extend free movement in the maritime sector for navigation within the European Union.
I share with the rapporteur the aim of this directive, which is to exempt all maritime freight transport within the European Union from unnecessary administrative formalities.

In fact, to achieve a European maritime space without borders, it is not only important that the various competent authorities cooperate satisfactorily, but also that the various simplification systems be applied simultaneously.
This is necessary to ensure the smooth functioning of the entire European maritime space without borders, to make sea freight transport more attractive and to optimize its use.

Harmonizing administrative procedures among Member States will enable smoother navigation between the various ports of the European Union and boost maritime freight traffic, which currently accounts for less than ten percent of the total.
To date, navigation continues to be hindered by the administrative formalities imposed upon it.
Electronic systems should therefore be brought into operation as quickly as possible, as this would allow for a faster data exchange system.

Furthermore, interoperability is crucial for achieving genuine administrative simplification. Indeed, the transmission of information via email is not fully efficient and proves useless if information systems are not technically interoperable.
As for language, I believe that the use of a common language would certainly benefit European maritime navigation.
In this way, communication would be more efficient, causing less confusion and reducing administrative delays.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, first of all, I would like to congratulate our rapporteur, Mr. Kramer, in particular, because we all know that we have truly achieved a result that sometimes seemed unlikely.
I would like to remind you that this directive, this file, was indeed considered a file at risk of entering a conciliation procedure.
So, it is evident to all from the Commissioner's words that we are faced with a task that has been complex and has required a great deal of time.
Consider, for instance, a directive dating back to 1956, and that this work leads us to the fifth and most significant amendment to the Industrial Emissions Directive.
Just these few data, I believe, tell us alone of all the shortcomings and also the defects of this regulation.
A directive that is difficult to implement; I would like to recall that nine Member States are subject to infringement procedures, and with a scope so broad as to sometimes be inappropriate.

We must not hide from ourselves that this has entailed considerable efforts, requiring sacrifices from all the institutions involved, all political groups, and all national delegations, and has often placed us before truly difficult choices.

However, I am here this evening to state with conviction that, in my opinion, we have achieved the best possible outcome for the protection of competition, the environment, and European industrial and employment policy.
We truly have, on the one hand, a directive that imposes common obligations on all Member States, but on the other hand, a directive that also allows for the flexibility that is necessary.

Here, I truly hope that the outcomes of this recast will be, in the short term, the reduction of administrative burdens and, in the medium term, the improvement of environmental performance and the strengthening of the European industry.
Mr. President, I would like to highlight the situation in which the crisis places us, facing a reality that for too long has not been given the importance it deserved.
that is, the instability in Central Asia, which unfortunately is growing, while the hopes for democracy and economic progress, at least in some of these countries, prove to be particularly fragile.

Kyrgyzstan has endured extremely violent clashes over the past month, which will leave, at least in the immediate future, a legacy of interethnic hatred that will make the stabilization of the country even more challenging than it was before.
The task of the international community and the European Union in particular, as has already been stated, is to assist Kyrgyzstan as much as possible under three aspects.
emergency supplies and the reconstruction of destroyed homes. Secondly, by providing the longest-term economic aid possible with regard to the European Union within the framework of its

strategy for Central Asia and the instruments implemented in this context, through political support to back the process of returning to constitutional legality and the establishment of a genuine rule of law.
The constitutional referendum, held on June 28th amidst a crisis and under obviously very difficult conditions, can be considered a first step on the path towards a return to constitutional order.

The electoral process on June twenty-eighth, among other things, received a positive judgment from the OSCE observation mission, which obviously took into account the special conditions under which the referendum was held.
The new constitutional order of Kyrgyzstan will be more oriented towards a parliamentary system than a presidential one.
This may allow for a better consideration of the country's diverse ethnic makeup and the need to garner consent from the various components of such a fragmented and composed nation.
The European Union and Crimea are bound by a Partnership and Cooperation Agreement which provides for regular meetings of a Parliamentary Cooperation Commission.
It is our hope that our interparliamentary relations can resume as soon as possible with the participation of a credible, democratically elected Parliament.
In the immediate term, as already mentioned, the crisis requires stability and our political-economic aid. Let us strive not to be stingy in either aspect.
Mr. President, honorable members of the European Council, whom no one voted for, today we also have a rotating Presidency in the hands of a government disavowed by its own citizens.
This alone is enough to understand why Europe is in the midst of a profound crisis, a Europe that has become a political paradox in the hands of a political elite with which citizens do not identify.
The program of the Belgian non-Presidency discusses structural reforms, employment growth, financial stability, and competitiveness, and the chosen instrument would be the EU 2020 strategy.
The current crisis, however, should push Europe towards ingredients vastly different from those which led to failure.

A comprehensive rethinking is necessary, because the crisis is not the mirror of decline, but rather the death certificate of the European social model that europropaganda would instead prescribe as a cure.
Today, Europe is an immense structure crumbling under the weight of democracy, centralism, and obstacles to free enterprise.
To emerge from the crisis, Europe must change its vocabulary: more decentralization, less bureaucracy, more concrete actions, and greater attention to the real problems of citizens.
Everything else will only inexorably accelerate decline.
Mr. President, I thank you, I apologize. I would like to emphasize in my intervention how the progressive erosion of European farmers' incomes to the detriment of growing...
the profit margins of the agri-industrial supply chain are causing a concerning economic marginalization of those working in the agricultural sector, leading to the abandonment of these activities.
Thus, a change of course is imperative, which the European Commission itself acknowledges and which the report under discussion in the House this morning recognizes.

The text translated from Italian to English is:

this morning's endorsement by the Assembly, to which I wish to express my support, is underscored by ample motivations and suggestions, including those of a legislative and behavioral nature.
Indeed, it is necessary to combat global speculation on raw materials and ensure supply security.

Furthermore, there must be guaranteed improved price transparency that not only ensures justice and dignity for farmers, but also corrects the significant imbalances in bargaining power and prevents abuses among the various operators.
Agriculture must reassert itself as the sector of economic and social stability and regain its power within the European Union's commercial context.
Mobilism and myopia, this is the diagnosis of the malaise affecting today's Europe 27.

The high mobility of labor, given that in Italy one in four young people is unemployed and there are sixteen million unemployed in the eurozone, is also due to the fact that no concretely effective action has followed the noise of europropaganda in recent months.

Myopia because Europe, in indicating the way out of the crisis, not only presented the usual recipe but completely lost sight of the most autologically territorial dimension of economic and social cohesion policy.

Only by placing territory at the heart of political action, and by respecting its unique cultural vocations, can European policies for development and employment be reignited, drawing on the natural energies that each geographical area expresses through its districts, small and medium-sized enterprises, and craftsmanship.
To solve the employment problem, we must first think small, invest in local authorities, and prioritize subsidiarity while safeguarding a heritage of linguistic and cultural diversity.
If the needle of the European compass does not guide its policy towards the territory, the shipwreck of the Europroject is a certainty.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, in building a Europe of rights, a central place is occupied by freedom of information, pluralism of information, and the independence of the media.
Has the Commissioner, Madam Commissioner, noticed that there is a country in the European Union, moreover a founding member through the Treaty of Rome, where it does not exist.
There is information pluralism, where a Prime Minister directly or indirectly controls public and private television and the print media.
How can there be democratic electoral competition in a country where a Prime Minister or a political party controls the media?
What democracy can there be in a country where a law is set to be approved in the coming days that does not allow journalists to publish judicial news stories?
Nothing like Watergate, nothing like a watchdog press, a lapdog for the regime. What kind of democratic country is it where they want to put the internet under control?
What kind of democratic country is it where those who challenge the dominant ideology are marginalized and the free expression of thoughts and dissent are not guaranteed?

We are not describing Sudan under Bocassa, nor Romania under Ceausescu, nor Italy under Berlusconi, where, unfortunately, this occurs because the European Commission lacks the courage to assert an independent and free stance vis-à-vis the Member States.
The completion of the internal market for postal services by the end of this year is an important step, but it would

It is appropriate that the Commission conduct an impact assessment, as some colleagues who spoke before me have reminded us, of the opening of the postal market, in order to better understand the needs of citizens.

How does the Commission intend to protect the right of European citizens living in hard-to-reach areas, such as mountainous or rural regions, to receive mail regularly, and what tools does it plan to employ to ensure this?
I also believe that this directive, which already exists, should not be used as a tool to justify the issue of social dumping.
It is the member states that are responsible for implementing the directive and they have all the tools to do so.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, colleagues, today's debate on readmission agreements cannot avoid the now thorny issue concerning the agreement between the European Union and Libya.
We know that part of the agreement focuses on combating illegal immigration.
We are concerned because, up to now, the Commission has told us little about this, despite the Treaty of Lisbon requiring the Commission to inform the Parliament in a timely manner.
Libya, as is well-known, has not signed the Geneva Convention on Human Rights, nor has it, to date, shown any indication of behaving in accordance with international law.

I think of the case of Eritrean immigrants detained in inhuman conditions at the Brak center in Libya, or again the closure of the UNHCR offices, but above all I think of what happened last week, when a Libyan Republic patrol boat opened fire.

against an Italian fishing vessel from the port of Mazzara del Vallo, in international waters, on the grounds of the presence on board of illegal immigrants, a most serious justification that leads us to believe that the agreement signed between Libya and Italy, which

provides, among other things, for the repatriation of immigrants to Libya without provisions regarding the right to request asylum and individual case-by-case examinations of their situations, and also includes the possibility of using firearms to stop immigrants.
Since part of the agreement is also secret in this case, I wonder if the Commission is aware of its content, and if it does not deem it necessary, in this specific case, to request clarifications.
The Commission has proposed the possibility for Libyan authorities to open fire on vessels if there is suspicion of irregular immigrant transportation.

On the economic front, it is positive for Europe to strengthen trade relations with its rapidly growing neighboring countries. However, the EU has always pursued, at least in words, a trade policy towards third countries, taking into account social and humanitarian aspects.
We must then firmly assert these clauses against Turkey, an Islamizing country where the condition of women is progressively deteriorating.
women killed in 2009 in cases of domestic violence, a country where Christians live in fear of attacks by Islamic extremists, one need only recall the brutal murder of Monsignor Padovanese.

In the report, the Parliament encourages Turkey to take a leading role in promoting fair and open trade. One thing is certain: we must be concerned about the political leadership role that Turkey is seeking to carve out in the Arab world.

friendship that Turkey is cultivating with Iran and terrorist groups such as Hamas. Nevertheless, if a trade policy must be, so be it, but this should never become the Trojan horse to facilitate Turkey's entry into Europe.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, Mr. Commissioner, with this measure, we aim to strengthen and rationalize the pharmacovigilance system of the European Union.
These are the ambitious objectives set out in the McEwan reports, which respectively amend Regulation 726 and Directive 2001/83.
Thanks to close and efficient cooperation between the Council and the European Parliament, as well as the relevant parliamentary committees.
to reach the discussion today of a proposal aimed at enhancing the Community pharmacovigilance system and refining the substantial and decades-long work of the European Union in this field.

Simplification, transparency, and rationalization can be considered key points of these two relations, which propose measures aimed at ensuring the best possible protection of public health, based on harmonized standards across Europe.

Reference is made, in fact, to a wide range of interventions that span from a better definition of roles and responsibilities of the main national and supranational stakeholders to a new and more consciously active involvement of the patient.

recognizes a fundamental actor role within the system, in strengthening the transparency of information concerning the safety of medicines, in simplifying communication activities, and in the registration and evaluation of reported adverse drug reactions.
The current pharmacovigilance system needs to be improved, also through closer collaboration at European, national, and regional levels.
Effective participation at all three of these levels will indeed ensure a fruitful exchange of information regarding the side effects of medications.
The new pharmacovigilance system will be able to provide a high level of shared and secure information for the benefit of patients, national authorities, and healthcare professionals.
Mr. President, just in these days here in Brussels, the men who fought the war have gathered.

Many representatives from municipalities and regions discussed how to tackle the serious problems affecting the lives of our cities, the old and new needs that impact workers, families, and small and large productive businesses.
The economic crisis that has struck our societies has made it harder and more challenging for all to provide adequate responses to a new, serious social issue.
In this context, I believe everyone has realized that the cohesion policy has been, on many occasions, the only concrete tool available to the regions to try to provide answers.
Therefore, we can say that the cohesion policy has been, in recent years, for all regions, an essential lever for the process of European integration.
Now we find ourselves redefining this policy for the post-2000 era, and thus we are at a turning point.
For this reason, it is vital to avoid certain risks.
The first fundamental point is that renationalization would be a significant step backwards.

Then, in drawing up the financing budget, it is necessary to ensure an adequate request, both with regard to the weaker realities, and at the same time with regard to the ability not to penalize the most competitive and advanced regions.
Finally, it is essential to simplify procedures for those who have proven to be efficient and to strengthen the ability to sanction those who have not been.
We expect the Commission to move in this direction.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the path towards a Europe that is inclusive and supportive of women is still long and challenging.
The statistics are clear: the global crisis has hit the labor market hard, severely testing female employment, which in 2008 decreased further by seven tenths of a percentage point.

Despite the provocations regarding equal opportunities and employment that periodically fill a declining pro-European propaganda, to date, no concrete measures have been adopted to ensure women genuine fulfillment as workers and as mothers.
The Europe of the future needs to radically rethink its welfare model rather than merely changing its label periodically.

Therefore, it is positive that the relative directive aligns the institution of maternity leave in Europe, but it is inefficient to address, on the margins of this subject, in the same report, the complementary and equally important issue of paternity leave.

The greater integration of women is not only a moral value but also a strategic goal for the sustainability of the much-touted European social model, which continues to fail to convince me due to its lack of results.
The rapporteur for the Development Committee, Mr Mitchell, has asked me to stand in for him as he is unable to attend today.
I thank you for the work carried out with your usual punctuality and for the quality of your proposals, which have received a favorable, I would say unanimous, opinion from the Development Committee.
Given what I will say, but especially in light of the work that my colleague Michel has done to date, I am convinced that the report can be adopted by a large majority.
But now I come to the report.
In the course of 2009, the European Commission presented a proposal to amend Regulation 1905/2006 establishing a financial instrument for development cooperation.
With this proposal, the Commission had requested that Parliament approve an amendment allowing non-governmental organizations to benefit from tax advantages when operating in developing countries.
proposal accepted by us.
But the cooperation and development regulation also includes the implementing rules for the European Union's development policy.
These regulations stipulate that when the Commission is to allocate funding, it must adhere to the comitology procedures.

This means that the Parliament has the power to scrutinize these funding proposals and, in cases where the Commission exceeds its powers, the Parliament may adopt resolutions to request that the Commission change the decisions in question.

Only from 2006 to the present has Parliament deemed that in at least twelve cases the Commission had exceeded its implementing powers, but in only three of these cases did the Commission actually amend or withdraw its proposal for a decision.
Following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the Development Committee proposed to apply the procedure for delegated acts provided for in Article 299 of the Treaty of Lisbon.
The adoption of these procedures would mean that, at least in the strategic funding decisions that the European Commission must adopt, Parliament would play a more significant role.
In fact, according to the Treaty of Lisbon, in certain well-defined cases, the Parliament can delegate to the Commission the power to make strategic decisions.
In our view, the choice of countries to which the European Union should provide development aid

This is a decision that rests with the legislator. So, which sectors should be prioritized for funding: education, health, environmental protection, good governance capabilities, or small business development?
And how can transparency be ensured in the management of development aid?
These are the choices and matters in which the European Parliament should play a more significant role than it has in the past.
It is here that the legislator must provide precise guidelines to the executive.
And it is precisely in this direction that, I believe, the demands of European citizens are ultimately heading.
I truly hope for the widest possible consensus for this report by Mr Mitchell.
to the rapporteur. On policy

An integrated Maritime Union needs to move beyond the stage of good intentions and provide a new impetus to a strategy that will serve as a catalyst for the growth and development of the European Union, addressing the immense delays accumulated in the prevention of environmental disasters, in the fight against climate change, and in tackling pollution.
Just this morning, our colleague Pirillo reminded Parliament of yet another catastrophic event that occurred in recent days in the city of Paola, Calabria.

The Commission must demonstrate practicality, not only by employing governance tools but also by implementing precise legislative measures, drawing the necessary lessons from past errors, which were often due to an overly sectoral approach.
There is full awareness that this process is very complex, but we are in the midst of a difficult and challenging crossing that cannot tolerate distractions and requires adequate investments and

participatory governance mechanisms, both at the interinstitutional level and in international cooperation for regional basins, among which the Mediterranean stands out for the complexity of its jurisdiction.
It will be fundamental, therefore, to understand the management of the Mediterranean basin as a common heritage of all the coastal states, based on the principle of

Conversely, the increasingly common practice of unilaterally declaring exclusive economic zones or similar areas in the Mediterranean Sea, in addition to being at odds with the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, would undermine the concept of effective and shared governance.

In this regard, I recall that just a month ago this interpretation by Libya led to a genuine armed assault on a European fishing vessel, and it would be wrong to claim that this is solely an Italo-Libyan matter.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I would like to thank Ms. Meissner for her report on integrated maritime policy. I agree with the rapporteur on the need to strengthen maritime transport and shipbuilding, as well as to protect coastal regions and promote innovation and research activities.
Today, maritime transport plays a crucial role in the commercial sector.
For this reason, cooperation between small and large ports overlooking the same sea basin should be encouraged, as it can facilitate a more fluid commercial exchange.
Furthermore, to ensure intermodality, it is necessary to invest in port and interport infrastructure, especially in ports that can be connected to European corridors.
Finally, I believe it is important not to overlook another issue, namely port security.

It is necessary to homogenize all security measures across all European ports in order to better protect maritime transport and prevent unfair competition at the expense of those ports which, in order to guarantee greater security, must incur higher costs.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, thirty years ago Morocco denied for many years that there was a war with the Sahrawi people; today, it is denying that there is disproportionate repression against the same people.
Yet in Western Sahara, there are deaths and injuries among a population that merely claims the right to live in freedom on their own land.
Morocco has effectively closed its borders to anyone who might bear witness to these events.
No information and no representatives.
access was denied to a French parliamentarian and our colleague Meyer.
Europe passively observes.
There is no sign in the Commission's communication that subordinates us to UN mediation, which continues to fail as it has for the past thirty years.
There is no position taken by Lady Ashton, who has responsibility for foreign policy.
It is necessary to react with a position taken by the Parliament.
It is necessary to react against Morocco by halting all initiatives regarding trade agreements, starting with the renewal of fishing agreements.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, my intervention is not intended to be the usual Euroskeptic rhetorical exercise, but rather an impetus for the EU to start focusing more on content than on form, and to abandon propaganda in favor of concreteness.
With the Lisbon strategy having failed, Europe has come up with a new EU 20-20 slogan, but in reality, it has not provided any innovative responses to employment issues.

The data confirms the unemployment rate in Europe at 9.6%, and 20.2% for youth. In Italy, the third largest net contributor to the EU budget, the situation for young people is even more dramatic, with 25.9% of youth without employment.

In the Europe I envision, there is no waste of resources in promotional campaigns, but rather efficient investments to ensure that the educational offerings prepare professionals for the sectors of the internal market where there are concrete employment opportunities.
I conclude by emphasizing the importance of investing in vocational training, a symbol of the excellence of our regions.

The world of craftsmanship offers a wealth of employment opportunities and a unique heritage of knowledge, which should be entrusted with the task of supporting the competitiveness of the European system.

Mr. President, Commissioner, Madam President of the Council, the European will to set ambitious goals in the run-up to the next climate change conference is certainly a commitment to pursue with tenacity and the awareness that the results will condition the future of our planet.
But it is precisely for this reason, dear colleagues, that we must be realistic and more cautious in our expectations.

The preparatory international negotiations leading up to the Cancun conference, as far as we know, not only did not make significant progress towards a global agreement, but also confirmed suspicions and resistances towards the commitments made in Copenhagen.
China has already been mentioned, but I would like to cite it here as well.
China allows itself, for example, an increase in its CO2 emissions of five billion tons by 2020, with consequences that could be offset.
and perhaps not even that, but only an attempt at compensation through a hundred percent reduction in European industrial emissions by the same year, by 2020.

This data not only renders futile the proposal for an unconditional thirty percent reduction, which we strongly oppose, but also leads many independent observers to hypothesize a significant increase in global emissions by that date.

In this contradictory situation, it would be at the very least speculative and even demagogic to hypothesize numbers and outline suggestive but unrealistic scenarios, where unknown variables inevitably impact the cost dimensions.

The hope is that the European Union brings to Cancun a shared, realistic, and sustainable proposal, because an agreement that yields tangible and perceptible results is always and in any case preferable to...

Inevitably doomed to failure and making government efforts on major environmental issues increasingly incredulous in the eyes of international public opinion—this would indeed be a hardly reparable damage.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I have one regret in this Chamber tonight as we discuss the Sahrawis only because the Moroccans have invaded the tent camp outside and the UN, and this is a regret for democracy in this Parliament.
The Parliament should have developed the will to discuss this issue on its own, an issue that has been rotting on international tables for thirty years.
This is the most significant political fact.
We were forced by acts of violence, not because we autonomously decided to have human rights guaranteed.
For what is it if not the respect for human rights, the fact that there should be a referendum for self-determination there?

It is precisely because Morocco is our friend, because Morocco is the strong party in the relationship, that we must firmly and with all consequent actions demand that there be an indispensable will that can no longer be postponed.
We must strive to create the conditions whereby the Minuso e Chiuso mission is not solely responsible for establishing the prerequisites for a referendum that is continually being postponed.
We must strive to utilize all the resources available to the European Union to influence this event and ensure that the referendum does justice to the thirty years of suffering of a people.
Mr. President, apart from this issue, I wished to raise a matter with the Presidency.
I believe that some still have not fully understood what the role of the European Parliament is after the Treaty of Lisbon.

I am compelled to raise a fundamental issue here. Transport Commissioner Callas repeatedly refuses to meet with the Sky and Space board to discuss the CESAR project, which is of interest to all from an economic, environmental, and safety perspective.
I invite the Presidency to call Commissioner Callas to the chamber and explain what program he intends to pursue in this area, which is extremely delicate and important to the European Parliament.

Colleagues, the report under discussion certainly contains positive elements. The general orientation is towards simplifying procedures and streamlining bureaucratic steps for workers from third countries with valid residence permits in the Member State.

However, as a point of reflection, I would like to remind you that today in Europe, tens of millions of citizens, including many young people, are unemployed due to the structural shortcomings of the European production system and as a result of a crisis that seems never-ending.

Even before considering third-country nationals residing in our countries, it is imperative that Europe focus primarily on implementing economic, political, and social measures to assist our citizens, above all, in finding or regaining employment.
If Europe can provide employment for its citizens, it will create a solid social foundation to adequately accommodate migratory flows from outside.
The watchword must be, first and foremost, to foster Europe's growth on its own two feet and through its own resources.
our countries will then have the
Thank you, President. Currently, access to employment is regulated only for certain specific categories of citizens from third countries.
In fact, not everyone benefits from the general principle of equal treatment in access to employment.

In this context, the European Union must act to ensure fair treatment for both third-country nationals legally residing within Member States and beneficiaries of refugee status or those in need of international protection, as per Directive 2003/83/EC of 29 April 2003.

It is necessary to prevent a growing demand, for example, for seasonal staff solely because they are paid less or because they have different, lower costs compared to a European citizen recruited for the same job.

One must avoid, for instance, the risk that many multinationals relocate their headquarters to countries like Morocco or Turkey and send their employees to work in European branches because it is cheaper.
For reasons of social justice, ensuring the same treatment of European citizens in terms of remuneration, working conditions, and social security is fundamental.
For this reason, I believe it is right that seasonal workers, posted workers, refugees, and self-employed workers are included in this directive.
Making differences will become extremely dangerous.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, human trafficking, according to estimates by international organizations and law enforcement agencies, is now the second-largest source of profit globally for organized crime, after drug trafficking.
It is estimated that approximately thirty million people are victims of organ trafficking, prostitution, and forced labor.

This means that, first and foremost, the fight against this criminal phenomenon of vast proportions is a battle for the safety of our citizens, against clandestinity, and against the crime that breeds crime.
In the face of a phenomenon of this magnitude, Europe must rightly implement drastic measures against those who exploit humans in various forms.
In combating this phenomenon, cooperation between Member States and between law enforcement agencies is necessary, but above all, there must be certainty of punishment for traffickers.

exploited because in their countries of origin they do not find dignified living conditions, they live in poverty and despair, and they are willing to do anything to leave their homeland for the promise of a better life that will not be fulfilled.

Europe, therefore, in addition to preventing crime and protecting victims of trafficking, must commit itself more diligently to ensure that these individuals can find acceptable living conditions in their own countries.
Acceptable. "Helping them in their own countries" must be the guiding principle of European political action so that our efforts are directed, in addition to repression, also towards prevention.

# Titolo: La Traduzione come Arte

## Introduzione

La traduzione è un'arte raffinata che richiede non solo una profonda conoscenza delle lingue, ma anche una sensibilità culturale e una maestria linguistica. In questo viaggio attraverso le parole, ci immergiamo nell'affascinante mondo della traduzione italiana-inglese, esplorando le sfumature e le sfide che esso presenta.

## La Sfida della Traduzione

Tradurre non è semplicemente sostituire parole da una lingua all'altra. È un processo complesso che coinvolge la comprensione del contesto, la cattura dell'essenza del testo originale e la sua riproduzione in una nuova lingua con fedeltà e grazia. L'italiano, con la sua ricchezza di espressioni idiomatiche e la sua musicalità, presenta sfide uniche per il traduttore.

## Adattare e Preservare

L'obiettivo principale di un traduttore è di adattare il testo alla nuova lingua, preservando al contempo il suo significato e il suo impatto originale. Questo richiede una scelta attenta delle parole, una comprensione delle strutture grammaticali e una sensibilità per le differenze culturali. La traduzione deve fluire naturalmente, come se fosse stata scritta nella lingua di destinazione fin dall'inizio.

## Esplorare le Sfumature

La lingua italiana è nota per le sue sfumature e sottigliezze. Espressioni come "fare una passeggiata" (che implica un'azione rilassata) e "andare a spasso" (che suggerisce un movimento più casuale) richiedono una traduzione attenta per catturare la sfumatura di significato. Il traduttore deve essere un artista, dipingendo con parole per evocare la stessa atmosfera e emozioni del testo originale.

## Conclusione

La traduzione italiana-inglese è un'arte che richiede dedizione, competenza e una profonda comprensione di entrambe le culture. È un processo creativo che trasforma le parole, mantenendo intatta la loro essenza. Attraverso questa pratica, i traduttori diventano ponti tra culture, facilitando la comunicazione e arricchendo la nostra comprensione del mondo.

I met the victims in a country where rape is conceived as a tool of war, where armed groups continue to
repeatedly practicing mass rapes and other systematic crimes against civil society, especially against women, the elderly, and children.
I wanted to mention the example of the Democratic Republic of the Congo because, as I was saying, it was a very recent experience of mine.
But the appeal I want to make is generally aimed at the need for a strong and continuous condemnation of the brutal violations of women's rights.
The international community must significantly increase funding for initiatives aimed at protecting women from rape and other forms of violence.

The disease in question has severe implications not only for health, but also for the well-being of those affected by it,
But the costs that must be borne for direct and informal care are indeed high.
Alzheimer's disease indeed does not only affect those who are diagnosed, but it also involves everyone who cares for them.

A European response to the problem is therefore necessary, along with global coordination among member states and a synergy of concerted actions focusing primarily on the scientific and research fields, and addressing the issue at hand.

enhancement of prevention, diagnosis, and the improvement of available care, including innovative approaches, as well as the dissemination of information among States on the achievements attained within them, thereby increasing the level of understanding of the disease.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the situation that the region, in particular the city of Naples, has been experiencing for quite some time is, unfortunately, known worldwide, and the European Union has had to address the issue on multiple occasions.

Confronted with this now paradoxical third-world-like situation, I therefore ask the Commission what consequences Italy will face from the perspective of Community law and what economic sanctions may potentially be imposed on Italy if the waste crisis in the countryside does not find a definitive solution in the short term.

I further ask whether the Commission can provide in detail the data concerning the European funds that have so far been managed by the Region of Campania for the creation of an integrated waste collection and disposal system.
You see, Commissioner, usually when we speak of an emergency, we refer to dramatic, extreme situations that, nonetheless, find a solution within reasonable timeframes.
When a so-called emergency has lasted for over 15 years, clearly something is not working.

The Italian government in recent years has endeavored to do all it can to resolve the long-standing issue of waste collection and disposal cycles, but evidently, if today the streets of Naples are overrun with tons of waste,
Tons of waste, and the blame is primarily attributable to the local authorities of Campania and their total inability or lack of will to work towards finding a solution.

It is clear and absolutely beyond any doubt that the conditions in which Naples and Campania find themselves are due to the absence of effective management that has characterized municipalities, provinces, and regions for many years in the handling of waste management.
If separate collection, the first essential element of a functioning waste management plan, is not properly carried out, it cannot be the fault of the central government.

If the Italian government has had to send the army, as happened a few weeks ago and on other occasions previously, to replace hundreds of newly hired workers who suddenly and simultaneously fell ill, it is evidently not the fault of the central government.

If the emergency has hit Naples, while the situation is very different in the rest of Italy, for example in my region, Veneto, where separate waste collection has been carried out for years without problems and with a very high recycling rate, it means that the responsibilities for the emergency lie elsewhere.

on Campanian politics and local administrators, and above all on the strong complicity with organized crime, which has always sought and obtained immense profits from the waste business, thanks to the infiltration of the Camorra into politics and local governments.
Following the lies of the Berlusconi government, which took office in 2008 telling Italians that the waste problem was resolved, the European Union is right to take action.
to block funds to Italy until a sustainable waste management cycle is presented, one that is based on waste recycling and composting.

It is certainly not the plan presented by President Caldoro, which once again relies on uncontrolled landfills such as those in Chiayano, Taverna del Re, and Terzigno, even within the Vesuvius National Park, nor does it involve incinerators that cause death, tumors, or a genuine public health emergency.
Public funds in Campania, amidst the environmental crisis of these thirteen years, have solidified criminal ties between politics, both left and right, entrepreneurs, and the Camorra.

And in environmental matters, they are resolved through the criminalization of dissent, by criminalizing local communities, families, and the territory itself, as the Italian government has done by using force to suppress those who defend nature and the land.

International law recognizes as a political refugee anyone who, fearing persecution due to their race, religion, nationality, social affiliation, or political opinions, is outside the country of which they are a citizen.
Cesare Battisti is not a political persecutee.

Despite the cover provided by France for years, we are talking about a multiple murderer, either the perpetrator or instigator of four homicides, who hid behind the pretext of political struggle to escape life imprisonment.
It is shameful for a great country like Brazil to deny the extradition of an unrepentant criminal by granting him political refugee status.
Italian authorities and above all the victims' families demand to see this criminal brought to justice.
In the face of President Lula's insistence in denying extradition, the EU cannot leave the Italian government alone.

Europe has and must use all the diplomatic tools at its disposal to ensure that Italy obtains the extradition of Battisti, even at the cost of threatening to suspend cooperation agreements with Brasilia.
provide concrete support to the Tunisian people and their transitional government, in order to relaunch a Euro-Mediterranean dialogue that has been severely neglected in recent years.
The explosion of anger among the youth and the poor of the Maghreb and Egypt stems from the inequitable distribution of wealth and restrictions on the exercise of fundamental freedoms.

In North Africa, people are rising up and demanding more democracy, more economy, more participation, more work, and are looking with astonishment at the immobile old European continent, incapable of grasping the social transformations that have taken place in that region and of developing real policies of progress and peace.
Europe should pay more attention to human rights and democracy, foster more dialogue, collaboration, and real economic interventions.
Europe must open its doors and its heart to North Africa to make the Mediterranean a sea of peace.
Enough with the rejection of immigrants and the violent collaboration of countries like Libya. More investments, more welcome, more aid, and more Euro-Mediterranean policy are needed.
History demands it of us.
The resolution adopted today by a majority on the waste emergency in Campania is a very important signal.
The Campanian emergency becomes a European emergency and is a decision in favor of the Campanian citizens.
Say no to the allocation of funds that merely consolidate corrupt politicians, unscrupulous entrepreneurs, and the Camorra, yes to European funds if a credible plan is presented.

No to an environmentally compatible waste management plan, no to uncontrolled landfills in national parks, no to incinerators that produce dioxin. Yes, instead, to recycling and environmentally friendly methods.
and also say no to the criminalization of local community dissent, thus yes to legality.

This is a significant turning point, a warning for the Berlusconi government and the regional government led by Caldoro, who until now have done nothing but talk and consolidate cliques and the Mafia bourgeoisie.

of falsified medicines, leading to a positive and more comprehensive regulatory framework, capable of safeguarding the health of citizens and protecting them from the risk of serious consequences.

The method we are employing is an artifice, for which we are grateful to Mr Fraga, namely that of an oral question, to discuss something that should, instead, be a right of this Parliament following the Treaty of Lisbon.
I believe this practice should end; we cannot resort to a strategy to accompany a co-decision process.
Co-decision making occurs when it is nurtured in the stages where it matures.
Today we are holding this debate, the treaty will be concluded, it will move forward, and we will say yes or no at the end.

In substance, I would like to emphasize, agreeing with many points raised by my colleagues, the importance of measuring the effects of fisheries agreements to ensure they are not merely commercial agreements through which we purchase cephalopods at one euro per kilogram in Mauritania.

These must be able to measure both sustainability but above all the impact on that country's economy, understand how many jobs are changing, comprehend the rate of innovation for artisanal fishing, and assess the utilization of these resources.
not merely a straightforward commercial exchange, but rather a fishing agreement, with all its implications.
President, the favorable vote expressed for the report by Honourable Rivasi is the result of an assessment of the management of the H1N1 influenza.
2009, which is the 2009/10 that aims to establish general guidelines for conduct that will be valid in any future global health emergency situations.
The report, following a long and positive phase of revision, makes cooperation, independence, and transparency its main pillars.

It aspires to greater and better cooperation between the health authorities of the Member States and European institutions, so as to be able to establish a harmonized and common risk management approach.
The objectives are to assess the strategies of Member States regarding national influenza management plans, including vaccine stockpiles, the publication of names of...
all experts consulted by the European health authorities and an efficient relationship of trust with the media responsible for disseminating public health messages.

Mr. President, Mr. President, until today, the recommendations adopted by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean have been provisionally incorporated into Community legislation through the annual regulations on fishing opportunities.
These pertain to the conservation measures, management, exploitation, control, and commercialization for fishery products and aquaculture in the Mediterranean.
The permanent nature of these recommendations, however, requires a more stable legal instrument for their incorporation into Community law.
It is therefore appropriate to incorporate the aforementioned recommendations through a single legislative act, to which future recommendations may be added.
Today we have taken this action, which will enhance legal certainty while also constituting a significant step towards simplification.
At this point, the contracting parties of the CGMPM are obligated to ensure the full implementation of the agreed measures from the highest level.
A timely transposition was therefore necessary in order to make these international measures directly applicable to natural or legal persons at Community level and to ensure legal certainty.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I believe that the adoption of Ms. Podimata's report represents a significant step forward towards a more balanced, advanced, and robust economic and fiscal policy in the European arena.

It is now evident to all the urgency of equipping ourselves, as Europe, as a coordination between the twenty-seven countries, with economic and financial tools capable of governing the economy and not merely enduring it.
For this reason, the proposal to tax financial transactions has received great resonance, great discussion, and significant attention.

The fact that the majority of this Parliament voted for this regulation is an important and significant development, because for the first time, inaction was not an option, and instead, a step forward was taken.
I hope that the Commission and the Council continue on this path.

Madam President, I welcome the reports on equality between men and women and on women's poverty in Europe, and I am pleased that they are being discussed today, on the centenary of International Women's Day.

Despite Directive 2002-73 on equal treatment between men and women in relation to access to employment, vocational training, promotion and working conditions, further efforts are required to achieve its proper implementation.

It is sufficient to consider that, despite the level of female education having increased significantly in recent years and the number of female graduates now surpassing that of male graduates, women remain concentrated in traditionally female sectors that are often less remunerated. They also hold fewer positions of responsibility across all areas of society.

The lack of access to care services for dependent individuals such as children, disabled people, and the elderly, as well as to adequate leave schemes and flexible work arrangements, prevents women from working.

I would like to conclude by recalling the women around the world who are fighting for their most basic rights. I would also like our Assembly to express solidarity with the Iranian feminist associations that are taking to the streets today, calling on women to demonstrate without the IJA.
As all the colleagues who have spoken, we are finally returning to talking, and I hope we will soon return to acting as well, with precise choices in economic policy and a common industrial policy.
Thanks to the Lange report, the excellent work done by the colleague, and President Tajani's communication.

This choice signifies several important things. Firstly, as has been stated, the relaunch and recovery of the European economy and the sustainability of employment also lie, and perhaps above all, in the recovery and support of the global economy.
in the manufacturing sector, to the most advanced sectors and even to traditional ones, because there is a frontier that can still be addressed and it was not so obvious until recently.

Secondly, the recovery of industrial sectors in Europe also means that our competitiveness does not lie in the financial and tertiary sectors, but rather here, and it is not too late for us to aim for an European challenge to regain competitiveness compared to the rest of the world in industrial sectors.

Third point, it has been stated that the new industrial policy focuses on factors rather than sectors, on the factors and tools that can truly promote new businesses and new resilience and updating capabilities.

I believe it is important to highlight, as has been done, these new factors that require action, namely credit. We are calling for new initiatives, in addition to those already announced by the Commissioner, on the issues of credit, raw materials, and energy costs.

innovation, research, and the need to enhance Europe's capacity for technological transfer, applying the outcomes of research and innovation within companies, in new products, and in novel production organization methods.

We have a very peculiar fabric to valorize in our Europe, and in some countries in particular, that of SMEs, the quality of businesses, the quality of products, in short, the peculiarity of industry in Europe.
And I believe that we should rediscover these manufacturing traditions, these manufacturing roots in many countries, to renew and transform them.
Finally, the theme of the territory, which is very important.
European policies are successful when they intersect with and find the terrain capable of addressing them.
So, thank you to Lange, and we look forward to excellent cooperation with the Commission to achieve tangible results in a timely manner.
Many milestones have been achieved, but some battles remain to be fought.
Today's urgency concerns women from other cultures living in Europe and around the world, in contexts where it is difficult for them to claim minimum standards of dignity and humanity.

We cannot celebrate this festival without placing at the forefront the issue of women in the Muslim Arab world, otherwise we continue to ignore a problem that today concerns them but will soon become ours as well.
We cannot ignore the emergency figures that are growing year after year, even in Europe, in our cities, in the schools where our children grow up.
For some time now, there has been a rise in cases of all manner of violence that Muslim women endure within their own families.

For this reason, I have been asking for some time and I reiterate today that Europe should implement targeted policies to counter the spread of Islamic radicalism, forced marriages, honor rights, female genital mutilation, and domestic violence.
As European women and men, we must fight for those women who live in Europe, but not only, who have no voice and are oppressed by the monster of Islamic integrism.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I voted in favor of the resolution on Turkey because the constitutional reform, which took place last December, was unanimously recognized as a significant step taken by Turkey towards Europe.
Of course, there are still many steps to be taken, and I express concern in this regard for the numerous arrests of journalists.

I emphasize that Turkey is the seventh-largest trading partner of the European Union, and the European Union is Turkey's primary trading partner. Trade, when correctly interpreted over the centuries, has fostered mutual understanding and peaceful relations between our peoples.

I therefore applaud the significant progress made in promoting links between the European Union and Turkey, especially those through the sea highways crossing the northern Adriatic and Tyrrhenian seas.
on which there is now a flow of over 250,000 TIRs per year in both directions, in connection with an important truck-to-wagon-to-sub-wagon rail link from the port to inland European destinations.
In this way, it has been possible to eliminate a significant amount of road transit by trucks, and I hope that this trend continues.
President, with today's vote we have given a further impetus to the definitive solution of this problem, but we have not voted for the best possible solution.

In fact, I would like to remind you that the over 300 amendments tabled to the report were transformed into 38 compromise amendments, all adopted, which aim to better define the priority areas of the strategy, as well as the objectives of this strategy.

The Commission, with the permanent task force, must ensure the collection and dissemination of statistical data and good practices, and Member States should appoint a government official, hopefully of a high level, to serve as a point of contact for the implementation of the strategy.

But we could have been even more forceful and less hypocritical if, in the report, we had focused on the obligations and duties that the Roma community should nonetheless observe in the host countries.
This is my hope, namely that solutions are found soon that allow for better coexistence of this community in all Member States.
Lampedusa has been invaded by tens of thousands of North Africans that the island could never possibly accommodate.
Italy has been targeted for weeks by hundreds of illegal immigrants' balconies.
And if we do not react together, if the EU does not react, the migratory wave of people in flight will continue.
The illegal immigrants who have arrived in recent months must be sent home, there is no alternative.
But the Italian government, beyond some words of solidarity, has been left alone to manage this biblical exodus of unpredictable proportions. Where is Europe?
Until today, Brussels has been conspicuously absent, displaying shameful behavior that my fellow citizens can no longer tolerate.
Europe has left Italy alone to face an unprecedented emergency.

Instead, Europe not only needs to assist Italy in the repatriation of illegal immigrants, but it must also support the efforts of the Italian government to prevent thousands upon thousands of people, especially from Tunisia, from continuing to depart.

A entirely different matter concerns Libyan refugees, for whom Europe must stand alongside Italy in operations of purification and logistical management. However, above all, Europe must commit to ensuring that refugees are hosted in all Member States.
The burden of welcoming those fleeing war cannot rest solely on Italy.
It's time to stop talking and take action.
The European Union, if it exists, let it make itself heard.
We cannot tolerate Italy being filled with clandestines while France repulses them with shameful methods.
Illegal immigrants should be sent back to their home countries, while all member states should commit, from this moment onwards, to welcoming Libyan refugees.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the issue of allocating adequate financial resources to ensure the decommissioning processes of nuclear facilities is a problem already addressed by the...

European Union legislation on nuclear sector safety and is highly relevant today, obviously in light of recent international events and the subsequent decisions of the Union's governments in this regard.

The work of Honorable Marinescu, to whom we have expressed our support, addresses the specific cases of certain countries that, at the time of their accession, assumed particular obligations regarding the decommissioning of nuclear facilities and that have received, precisely for this activity, special support from the European Union.
Beyond specific cases, it is imperative to establish an effective system of verification and inspection of nuclear power plants located within the territory of the Union.
Indeed, the number of reactors that are estimated to need decommissioning in the near future on Community territory appears to be high.

It will therefore be essential to establish guarantee mechanisms, especially in these cases, for the setting aside of adequate financial resources required to meet both ordinary and extraordinary needs.
I would also like to thank the rapporteur.
The report takes into account the new developments in control and communication systems.
For this reason as well, a picture of great heterogeneity emerges, especially on the part of the States in reporting irregularities and frauds.

The report repeatedly highlights the oddity of the low levels of fraud and irregularities reported by several countries concerning agricultural expenditures, structural funds, and pre-accession funds.
Indeed, there is a need to clarify the statistical data that has been presented.
The situation is further exacerbated by the issue of the ineffectiveness of recoveries.
However, one fact appears clear and confirms a long-term trend.

The struggle for legality and transparency in the expenditure of European resources, such as the fight against tax evasion and illusion, still cannot rely on the full cooperation of states, governments, and European institutions.

In this sense, I believe the calls for a revision of the Community legislation on public procurement and the need for what I call a European public register of beneficiaries of Community funds are appropriate.
I would like to thank the speakers and also Commissioner Barnier for his great willingness to engage with the Parliament.
We support the idea of an internal market capable of understanding and meeting social expectations and the implications that the social dimension entails.
This is not utopia, it is realism and also modernity.

It is indeed this vision that strengthens the market itself, because the purely economic element, economicism, in essence the reduction of the market to economicism, has shown that this does not solve either the problems of growth or those of cohesion.
In essence, it involves fully realizing, in the present, the distinctly European idea of a social market economy.
In today's texts, this is present.
There is recognition of social enterprises, cooperatives, their role, mutual societies, foundations, ten percent of European businesses, and a large part of our employment.
These are realities that are true businesses, demonstrating economic pluralism and business pluralism.

They work with capital but not for capital, and they aim to achieve labor, welfare, quality, and social innovation. They want to demonstrate that these values should and can be part of the internal market in Europe.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, Beijing's justification that artist Ai Weiwei was arrested for economic crimes is unconvincing, as is the notion that such relentless persecution is being directed at a free and dissident artist.
It does not convince, as this arrest is part of hundreds of arrests of opponents and the systematic repression of any dissent.

On the days when Arab uprisings explode, our thoughts turn to the image of cruel violence in Tiananmen Square against young Chinese who, like those today with the Jasmine Revolution, were asking for freedom and democracy.
China has opened up economically to the West, but it has not combined production with environmental respect and labor safety, and it fails to show any openness towards democracy and pluralism.

Our actions are not, as Beijing claims, interference in China's internal affairs. Rather, they are the plea of men and women, of movements, and of parties aiming to construct a world free from intolerance on every continent.
The Beijing government should look at what is happening in the world to understand whether, if it does not change, it will be the events of history and Chinese citizens who will change China.
Please.

This is the direct result in terms of impact on SMEs, in the triumphant project of Lisbon first and the Europe 2020 strategy, on which it has even been decided to focus the resources of the next Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020.

I can only reiterate what thousands of European citizens and taxpayers are asking: what is the point of Europe if it cannot solve the continent's economic problems, cannot speak with one voice on foreign policy, and wastes money?

I hope that the review of the SME code is truly able to simplify bureaucracy, ensure access to credit recovery, and facilitate digitalization.

If the costs of yet another strategy will once again only fund empty talk, I invite European institutions to make amends to the dozens of small business owners in my region, Veneto, who took their own lives before witnessing the failure of their small enterprises.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, as Europe turns a blind eye, the 2011 Europol report on organized crime states that with the entry of Romania and Bulgaria into Schengen, powerful Turkish, Russian, and Albanian criminal organizations will be able to expand their activities across Europe.
Again, to quote directly, illegal immigration from Turkey will spread to the coasts of Bulgaria, and drug and human trafficking under the control of Turkish-Albanian crime syndicates will increase.

Still on human trafficking, the entry of Romania and Bulgaria into Schengen could provide Bulgarian crime and new Roma communities with new opportunities to increase their already substantial trafficking towards the rest of Europe.
In essence, the increase in illegal immigration from Turkey and drug and human trafficking, results in reduced security for European citizens.
Europe wants to do a great favor to organized crime.
The Lega Nord party will always be opposed to this kind of reckless decision-making.
Those who vote in favor of this report tomorrow will bear the responsibility of a vote that will open an expressway for organized crime, leading straight to the heart of Europe.
Thanks to the Amsterdam Treaty, environmental policy and sustainability policy have gained greater relevance, and sustainability policy has become more important.
Attention has focused on the integration of economic policy with environmental policy and on incorporating environmental issues into policies and other sectors.

Key sectors include climate change, sustainable transport, nature and biodiversity, health and the environment, as well as the use of natural resources and waste management, along with the international dimension of sustainable development.
In June 2006, the European Council, in its conclusions, called on the Union and its Member States to extend national accounts to the key aspects of sustainable development.
National accounts should therefore be supplemented by an integrated economic and environmental accounting system, capable of providing fully consistent data.
I voted in favor of this regulation proposal because it creates new uses for national accounting data and environmental statistics and for other statistical sectors.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, my favorable vote on the Garriga report on the Union's upcoming financial perspectives stems from the conviction that it is precisely in one of the most critical moments that we must define a clear strategic vision for the future.
It is crucial for the so-called European spirit to insist on and prevail in the indispensability of providing the Union with credible tools, starting with an adequate financial endowment.
Therefore, the request for an additional five percent for the next budget is a fair and necessary request, perhaps not sufficient, but indispensable to address the major issues before us.
addressing real issues such as stronger cohesion among regions, enhanced research and innovation capabilities, and a greater ability to generate growth and provide employment.

unless adequate solutions are found to all these issues, starting with the introduction of this intermediate category in cohesion policy, which only makes sense if it does not harm the other existing categories.
This is why I voted in favor, and I hope that the Commission and the Council will follow the guidelines set out in this report.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the new Hungarian Constitution reduces the possibility of intervention by oversight bodies such as the Constitutional Court and increases the powers of the executive, thus calling into question the normal balance of powers.
Social rights are eroded; the state provides subsidies to those in need only if they agree to perform community service.
The right to self-defense is even enshrined, allowing individuals to possess weapons in their homes without a license.
The right to abortion is prohibited, and severely discriminatory rules towards homosexuals are introduced.
All of this is contrary to Directive 2000/78, which establishes a general framework for combating discrimination.

I therefore ask the Commissioner how she intends to act, considering that the fundamental rights of the new Hungarian Constitution are poorly compatible with those of the European Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.
We are about to vote on a highly significant strategic document that provides a solid framework for the negotiation on the financial perspectives beyond 2020.

starting with the request for coherence between objectives and instruments, between the new role that European institutions are called upon to play after Lisbon and in the face of recession, and the resources that we collectively decide to invest.
This consistency also implies a serious response to the demand for innovation emerging from public opinion, the beneficiaries of EU policies, and European social and productive forces.
We have done this for cohesion, a crucial chapter to decide what we want and what the European Union will be in the coming years.
it tells us that cohesion is today a vital node of the European project, an important heritage for all to safeguard, to protect, to renew.
Particularly critical on this front is the effort made to introduce an intermediate category of regions, especially because in several cases the recession years we have behind us have

exacerbated internal disparities, making efficient and adequate support for the less developed regions of Europe even more crucial. This involves combating waste and ensuring a clear vision for development policy.
However, I believe that the challenge of intermediate categories with the safeguard clause is one that we must embrace to usher in a new era in politics.
of cohesion in Europe and also to underpin the cohesion policy with the more balanced, more sustainable development that we want to ensure for Europe in the coming years.
I too would like to express my gratitude to Mr Langen and the other colleagues with whom we have worked to finalize this complex report.
I believe it is particularly important what the honorable member recalled.
Langen, when he stated that we aim to retain the purpose and scope of this regulation, remaining faithful to the mandate of the G20 in Pittsburgh in 2009.
The fundamental objective is to bring the majority of over-the-counter derivatives onto regulated platforms to avoid continuing to be exposed to a high degree of

risk and speculation. When we reach the point, as has happened, of trading and insuring four hundred million dollars without collateral, that is, without adequate reserves, we understand the risks we are taking.

Having said that, however, I would also like to touch upon two issues. The first issue concerns our relationship with the Council, and the second issue pertains to the coherence of the proposed reform of the financial markets, which we must pursue.

I raise the first issue concerning the Council, and I state this very clearly: the feeling is all too often that the Council represents an obstacle to acting quickly and effectively on the reform of financial markets.
I hope that the new Presidency will take up this issue, because even on this occasion we must contribute to the debate with concrete proposals.
I am accounting for an extension of the timelines, which is largely due to the positions, difficulties, and disagreements that emerge during the Council meetings.
It is a problem that also concerns the procedure we wish to follow.
The second issue concerns the organicity and specificity of the measures.
There is not only the measure on OTCs, there is the measure on short selling and other measures.

I wish to draw attention to two points concerning the specific issue of the raw materials market, a particular market requiring specific anti-speculative measures, and the problem of local authorities' exposure to derivatives in the countries of the European Union.
I believe these are issues that Parliament must address.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the Fukushima accident continues to produce very serious consequences, with the loss of sea and radioactive water at six hundred times the legal limits.
The risk of food products becoming contaminated is high.
Europe has established very strict controls, but this concerns only fresh produce.
No protective regulations have been issued for processed products, particularly canned fish.
We import three hundred and seventy thousand tons of canned tuna, with the main suppliers being Southeast Asian countries that import fish from Japan.
This means that canned fish imported into Europe may contain Japanese fish.
It is fundamental and urgent to provide precise information about the place of origin.
Today, in fact, consumers know where the box was produced, but not the location where the fish was caught.

The Commission has recently acknowledged this and plans to address this gap through the reform of the Common Fisheries Policy, which, however, will not enter into force for at least two years, just as the Sommer report, currently under discussion in this plenary session, will not take effect for three years.
We must not create panic, but consumers have the right to urgent and transparent information.
The Commission must intervene as soon as possible.
Mr. President Tusk, your speech gives us hope. We hope that the Polish Presidency will contribute to the fight against an Europe of selfishness.
nationalistic, with no vision for the future, but rather a contribution in favor of Europe, which truly thinks of itself as an integrated reality with a shared destiny.
But, as you rightly pointed out in your speech, a Presidency faces concrete problems that need to be addressed and resolved.
In this brief time, I wish to draw your attention to two crucial issues on the front of the economic and financial crisis.
First, let's address the reform of financial markets.

This is not a technical issue, it is a major democratic matter of our time. The timelines are too long, we need to resolve issues such as the reform of short selling and OTC (over-the-counter) transactions.
Second point, we have before us the issue of taxation on financial transactions. We need to delve into the specifics; we expect a concrete contribution from the Polish Presidency in this regard.
More than twenty years have passed since the signing of the Schengen agreements.
No one questions the benefits of free movement, but it must be acknowledged that the current arrangement is no longer adequate for present and future needs.

For this reason, Member States and the EU as a whole must commit to reviewing the functioning mechanisms of Schengen, so that the freedom of movement does not come at the expense of our citizens' legitimate security needs.

As far as we know so far, the Commission's guidelines may also be partly acceptable, especially regarding the introduction of a mechanism that allows states to temporarily reinstate border controls in case of emergency.
We must see, however, how this will happen and whether the declarations will be followed by actions, especially concrete results.

Certainly, there is also a need to embark on a comprehensive reform of the European border protection system, particularly at the external frontiers, where Frontex must become an agency with genuine powers of intervention and support for national authorities as soon as possible.
We must protect our external borders if we wish to continue with this Schengen.
It is time for courageous choices in this Europe if one does not wish to merely survive.

The crisis has deeply marked the real lives of European citizens and businesses, and risks, if we do not react, irreversibly lowering the social and cultural quality, well-being, and future of young people and Europeans.

More than cohesion and prosperity values, exiting the crisis means creating remedies for the identified causes, remedies against speculation, which, if necessary, must also have its claws trimmed, by imposing strict rules on financial markets.

remedies against the recession, remedies against an unbalanced development model that has placed the individual a step below profit, remedies against the resurgent nationalism that does prevent Europe from making the choices that rightfully belong to it today.

Above all, it is time to define the tools, resources, even new ones, to move forward, to ignite the engines of growth, through research, innovation, training, and support for productive investments, infrastructure, and labor, because without work, people are without dignity and rights.
This report, thanks to Pervance Beres and colleagues, outlines a possible strategy for a Europe proud of and aware of its role.
It is now up to European leaders, if there are any, to take responsibility for implementing it.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, behind the widespread prosperity of our continent lies a hidden, often invisible Europe, of which we speak in terms of numbers, statistics, and sociology, rather than as real people, often women, children, or the elderly, i.e., the most vulnerable population.
