But Europe will not be credible to its citizens if it does not learn to be consistent, and we here wish to be consistent in this Parliament, at this stage in Europe's life.

If we say that we are founding the Union on values, on human rights, I do not believe we can so drastically interrupt or cut a program for those who do not eat, for those who do not have the right to food, to access to food.

fundamental, for an unresolved legal issue, is an agricultural fund, it is a social fund and if it is to be social, Commissioner, it should not be at the expense of other social programs, but should be a new, ad hoc fund, with appropriate resources.
We claim to want to ensure food security for Europeans, but the primary right to security is to have food, and then for it to be healthy.
So here is our consistency and our commitment.
Therefore, let us find a legal solution that ensures continuity and, with the help of non-governmental organizations and volunteers, guarantees the first fundamental human right, the right to food.
Mr. President, solely to support this report and to highlight two aspects in particular: one, because it inserts itself into the ongoing debate currently taking place on

revision of the common fisheries policy and on the underlying option, which is the one related to the regionalization of a policy that, having been centralized in recent years, has shown all its weaknesses.
This phase of regionalization finds a particular application in the Black Sea.
I believe that the elements contained in Ms. Iotova's report describe a specific, but repeatable, situation across the rest of Europe; the situation with the Adriatic Sea is no different.
of the Tyrrhenian Sea or the Aegean Sea, that is, the interactions primarily between European fishing and non-European fishing are often very harmful to European markets and European consumers.
The second issue I would like to briefly highlight is the call for a common coastal guard.
There is no politics without an exercise of control.

Checks and controls today are carried out by disparate forces across Europe. I believe it is time to understand how one of the first European law enforcement agencies, namely the coast guards, could have a common management, greater coordination, and why not, a single European corps.
With this hope, I fully support the contents of the report by colleague Iotova.
Thank you, Mr. President. The disaster that struck the Gulf of Mexico over a year ago prompted the European Commission to reflect on legislation related to offshore oil platform activities.
The European Parliament, through this report, also sought to express its position on the matter, adopting a text that requires adequate technical and financial capacities.
for industry operators and aims to establish high safety standards, thereby cementing the European Union's leading role in promoting the safety of offshore activities.
The new measures in this field requested of the Commission must focus on international coordination and a realistic approach that combines all existing excellences.
in the sector at the procedural level and avoid the creation of new bodies or additional bureaucracy that could risk diverting from achieving concrete final objectives.

The report, in concrete terms, in addition to holding operator companies more accountable, calls for the improvement of communication mechanisms and the sharing of information and knowledge. It also advocates for the strengthening and expansion of the role and competencies of the European Maritime Safety Agency.
It is for all these reasons that I consider the result achieved to be positive, thanks to the negotiation of this text to which we have expressed our support.
I would like to thank colleagues Zeber and Schilakakis, as well as Commissioner Edegard.

I believe that we are here today discussing and reasoning in order to truly achieve a strong European climate policy, capable of safeguarding economic development and the well-being of European citizens.
International climate policies, as has been recalled thus far, have primarily focused on reducing CO2 emissions.
the proposal highlights how we must also tackle the fight against other anthropogenic emissions that cause the formation of tropospheric ozone, impacting climate change.

Numerous things have already been mentioned that I believe we should keep firmly in mind. Today, we are capable of achieving this at absolutely reasonable costs; we have the technologies at our disposal. While it is undeniable that CO2 emissions have a significant impact,

While it is undeniable that the other greenhouse gases present in the atmosphere are in much smaller percentages, there is no doubt that their potential is very high and that, therefore, we could truly achieve significant results in just a few years, in a few decades.
important.
There are signals, as the commissioner also reminded, I saw a study published in Nature by the scientific agency of the U.S. Department of Commerce, with which I find...

I believe there are many points of convergence with the analysis conducted by my colleagues, and therefore I envision that these could also be aspects that enable Europe to present itself in Durban with an even stronger, more tangible, and significant position.

I only finish by recalling, as has already been mentioned, that for the extraordinarily difficult and delicate moment we are living through—we were just discussing the homeless a few minutes ago—there is a sensitivity among European citizens that we must take into account, and therefore considering the great...

In terms of sensitivity, obviously, and for job positions, we should be able to launch a communication campaign that clearly explains to citizens what concrete actions we intend to take towards development, their well-being, and the protection of job positions.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the single market, free movement, and the Lisbon Treaty are all elements that have come into play regardless of a change in our legislative approach, both at the European and national levels.

It is necessary to follow up on the commitments that have arisen from these opportunities, in particular, it is necessary to genuinely initiate a phase of simplification of the legislative system, a simplification phase that must lead to a different dialogue between Europe and individual states.
I would start precisely with our documents, taking the opportunity to propose a kind of clarity test for our documents. When we produce a white paper or a green paper, it must be more understandable.

this virtuous stage of legislative initiation is to assign a specific mandate to a European Commissioner who will specifically focus on clarifying legislation and relations between states and Europe itself.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, representative of the Council, and Commissioner, first of all, I too would like to warmly welcome, as other colleagues have done, the anti-corruption package approved by the European Commission on June 6th.
Corruption is a transnational phenomenon and measures at the European level are necessary to combat it.
The vast majority of our European citizens, according to Eurobarometer estimates, believe that Europe should do more.
How can one fault them?

In many Member States, there has been a lack of political will to combat corruption; consider that there are still European countries that have not signed the United Nations Convention against Corruption.

When we consider the devastating impact of corruption on democratic processes, citizens' rights, and trust in the rule of law, it is clear that the national measures to combat it, adopted so far by the Member States, are insufficient to contain a phenomenon that is on the rise.

It is the European Union that must provide a unified and strong response, especially now, in the midst of an unprecedented economic crisis, which is impacting the lives of people, the resilience of welfare pension systems, and the ability of institutions to ensure essential services.
Corruption causes an annual loss of one hundred and twenty billion euros, equivalent to 1% of the European Union's GDP, and daily diverts resources from the Union and its Member States.
could be used to provide essential services such as education, childcare, employment, transportation, in short, diverting clean resources away from supporting people.

Therefore, it is necessary to show more courage and firmness, both by monitoring the implementation of anti-corruption measures and by stepping up and strengthening the measures to combat corruption at EU level.

In particular, we cannot speak of fighting corruption if we are unable to adopt at least minimum rules for the definition of the crime of corruption, of which there is no trace in the recently approved package.
The same applies to the definition of uniform parameters for measuring the extent of the phenomenon in the Member States, essential for developing an effective response.
We are in favor, for example, of revitalizing the network of EU contact points against corruption, as proposed in the resolution we will vote on tomorrow.
The crisis is not of recent origin; it has been ongoing for several years.
Perhaps it is time for a critical assessment of the policies followed so far. Has everything always been done well?
We have always conducted appropriate situational analyses.
the right approach has been chosen
The same European central bank, which as Minister Rostovsky says saved Europe, did it always do the right thing when, fearing inflation, it raised interest rates?
President Barroso identifies a problem: the speed of markets and the slowness of politics. But is this the only problem?

Certainly, if we consider that we are still operating under the implementation of July 21st, this should at least prompt us to better prepare and organize summits and their outcomes. However, politics will always be slower than markets.
The point, then, is to look further ahead, shifting the focus to unemployment reduction and development.
This is the path that the European Commission must choose. Even today, in President Barroso's speech, there was more concreteness on the deficit and less on indications of growth and development.

The Commission should overcome its weakness, state that the priority is fighting unemployment and creating jobs, redistributing wealth, and implementing a strategy of public investments, also changing the rules of the new European stability pact.
Mr. President, I believe that the challenge for the coming years is to ensure that Europe, as has been said, retains its leading position.
a global tourist destination and at the same time capable of enhancing, in terms of both environmental protection and competitive capacity, its entire territorial heritage.

It is a challenging and non-trivial task, especially in light not only of the opportunities, but also of the aggressiveness of other countries in this sector, from other continents, from China to India to Brazil.
Now, in this context, as Commissioner Tajani recalled, it becomes fundamental, as also noted in the opinion of the committee that we approved in the Regional Development Committee,
maintain a strong overall strategy for the entire European Union on tourism, while enhancing the role of regions and territories.
In this sense, it is essential to fully engage, from the outset, while respecting the principle of subsidiarity of the regions and local authorities.
Furthermore, I believe that the development of integrated tourist networks and projects should be encouraged, starting with the creation of partnerships for the exchange of best practices.
It seems right, indeed, to propose the identification of an 'Europe Brand' that can define a high quality of the tourist product.
Obviously, it will be up to the Commission to better define the priorities, especially from a financial standpoint, to ensure that this European primacy is maintained in the future.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the preparation of the common strategic framework for the funding of research and innovation represents one of the greatest opportunities that European development and economy have before them.

In fact, it is a matter of acting on the lever that can truly trigger a moment of growth and also of new qualified employment, such as that of researchers and young people who dedicate themselves to new opportunities for innovation, technology, and related professions.
One observation, above all, emerges from this work: we must increasingly emphasize in Europe a research and innovation that leads to practical application.
giving birth to new businesses that lead to new patents and do not remain purely basic research, pure knowledge—important, yes, but not enough to truly trigger the development sprint.

The second observation concerns the relationship with local authorities, regions, and territories, which are also an important tool for territorial programming and for the interaction between research, universities, centers of excellence, and businesses.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, European schools were established with the aim of ensuring access to education in one's mother tongue for the children of European institution staff who are called to work and live abroad in a cultural context different from that of their home country.
The first European school was established in Luxembourg in the distant year of 1953 at the initiative of a group of officials.
Over the years, given the positivity of this form of teaching, fourteen European schools have been established within the various Member States.

While acknowledging that the system of European schools represents a necessity rather than a luxury, it is evident that, more than fifty years after the creation of the first European school, this system may present outdated aspects and must in some way be updated and adapted to new economic and social needs.

I therefore expressed my vote in favor of the text by colleague Cavada, which aspires to greater involvement by the European Union to support and coordinate the actions of the Member States, called upon to work to develop and improve the system of European schools.
It is understood that investing in education means investing in the future of our young Europeans.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, in recent decades there has been an exponential increase in the number of natural disasters, which have caused the death of tens of thousands of people in various parts of the world.
Last year, within the Development Committee, I followed the work on the report on the European Union's disaster response capacity.
It became apparent how much more needs to be done to ensure a coordinated response by the European Union in the face of multiplying earthquakes, hurricanes, and tsunamis.
The European Union's response to the Haiti earthquake, for example, clearly demonstrated the complexity of existing instruments and procedures.

Although the Member States and Community institutions acted promptly in terms of sending humanitarian aid, the management of the crisis raised a series of issues in terms of efficiency, coordination, and transparency.

For this very reason, I expressed a favorable vote for the text presented by my colleague Elisabetta Gardini, which aspires to greater efficiency in all stages of disaster management, and improved coordination.
between the parties involved and a simplification aimed at avoiding unnecessary overlap and time-wasting that could hinder the provision of rapid and effective aid.
It is merely a good initiative, I believe that it will be a matter of constructing, instead, a European policy towards tourism.
The European brand is a good intuition, but I want to dwell on two issues. There is no sea or coastal tourism without a coastal planning policy.

I believe it is time for Europe, precisely to safeguard this important sector, to launch an initiative where the concept of the sea and the concept of the coast are not limited to a kind of urban planning that ends at the water's edge and does not comprehensively engage the sea.
I believe that an integrated policy in this direction is beneficial, as well as the need to build everything that lies behind the claims of rural tourism. Rural tourism can be
an excellent source of income for disadvantaged areas, for regions where there is no longer any work, where it is important to prevent further depopulation and encourage human settlement.

Well, it is not enough to make mere statements; one should suggest to Europe and individual states to intervene on the tax lever. Doing tourism in rural areas may mean paying fewer taxes, perhaps this is how a real opportunity for the tourism resource and for those who live there can be built.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to express my congratulations on the work done by Hon. Fidanza, which logically fits into the framework of the actions.
undertaken and promoted at the community level in the field of tourism, after the Treaty of Lisbon granted the EU new competences for the sector.
I share and wish to underscore the assertion of the importance of a unified Europe as the destination for certified and high-quality tourism, and the determination to promote this.
the same idea, translating it into actions at the level of structures, resource allocations, funding, and coordination of actions between the various levels of government of the Union's countries.
an approach that should be valued and rewarded, given the sector's implications in terms of GDP percentages produced, employment, and new opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises,
Businesses that focus on environmental protection and enhancement are better positioned to develop and address the key challenges of our time.
For all these reasons, I consider this report positive, an important signal in the direction of promoting a European policy for tourism.
Mr. President, for the recovery as well, three brief considerations: we need more Europe here too.
I believe it is inevitable that on certain issues there is truly an attitude where not only is more Europe desired, but it is also constructed.
More Europe means, for example, beginning to genuinely consider a common road police force, with identical rules in terms of safety protection.
More Europe means having a European policy on education, not simply delegating this to individual nations, but rather constructing, for instance, a genuine educational policy.
In relation to schools, in relation to young people, and also in relation to higher-risk groups, such as motorcyclists mentioned a moment ago, but this could also include truck drivers.
More Europe means having common tools within machines that improve safety conditions.
I believe they are a timely strategy to be developed with the automotive companies and European vehicle manufacturing.
Here, I believe that if all this is framed within the conviction of a common policy, I truly think that perhaps conditions will improve.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, this report tackles a subject that is global food security. Global implies that this issue is not solely about world hunger in the poorest countries, but that the matter of food supply concerns all communities, including those in the most developed nations.

draws some essential lines of coherence between European policies and this goal of global food security because we are an institution that preaches very well but often lacks consistency in its choices.
I merely want to highlight three titles of innovative lines that I believe we should further develop.
The first issue, food supply, is now at risk due to price volatility caused by speculation on food products, which needs to be contained if not prevented, including derivatives and the like.
Secondly, the issue of land grabbing, which I believe should be the subject of some form of treaty or negotiation, as democracy, as well as the survival of many peoples, is at risk.
Third, the consistency between energy supply and policies.
We cannot, in order to produce new energy, prevent the production of food for the world's populations.
I voted wholeheartedly in favor of this report by Mr. Zimmer, primarily for a matter of...
a purely political matter, as I believe it is necessary to bring the major issue of food security back to the center of the European Union's initiative.

It is not merely a matter of helping developing countries address this issue more effectively, but the food crisis, as it is forecasted that by 2050, the demand for food will increase by over seventy percent.

Agricultural products is a major issue that, if not addressed promptly and decisively, will become one of the main threats, if not the most significant threat, to stability, peace, and even democracy, as has been seen.

For this reason, I believe it is indispensable that the entire European Union, together with the Member States, make all necessary efforts, starting with appropriate economic investments, as indicated in the report, in this direction to seriously address this great issue.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, greetings to the Commission. I truly must thank all the people who have contributed in these weeks and months to the production of this document that we are voting on in the chamber today.
We worked, I must say, very well and a truly constructive debate developed.
The resolution proposal we are voting on today is the result of a truly collaborative effort and reflects the contributions of all political groups and the entire Parliament.
I believe a very strong common sensitivity has developed around this issue, also because, we must remember, we live in an era that is truly characterized by an exponential increase in catastrophes.
Numbers, when viewed in their raw form, are very eloquent. The number of disasters worldwide has quintupled, considering that in 1975
seventy-eight catastrophic events had been recorded, while today we find ourselves facing nearly four hundred disastrous events per year.

In the last twenty years, unfortunately, the victims of these disasters have numbered ninety thousand, and more than twenty-nine million individuals have been affected by the disasters, while the economic losses amount to two hundred and eleven billion euros.
It is evident that we are facing phenomena of such magnitude that they demand a stronger response, a more effective response, and a truly robust commitment from us.
We all have in our minds the images of the earthquake in Haiti, the flood in Pakistan, what happened in Japan.
Europe itself experiences sudden floods, fires, and let us remember the ash cloud following the eruption of the Icelandic volcano, all occurring on its own territory every year.
There is no need to belabor the point in asserting the significance of the work being done here in Parliament, guided by two principles.
fundamental principles, which are our guiding stars, the principle of solidarity, which is strengthened by the solidarity clause of the Treaty of Lisbon, and the principle of subsidiarity.
We operate along these lines.

The intervention of the European Union has been consistently generous and effective in the past, as evidenced, I believe, by the untiring work of our Commissioner Gheorgheva. However, today we need to make a qualitative leap.
A qualitative leap that we are ready to make to move from an ad hoc response to one where the reaction
is enhanced through the prior identification of existing resources in the Member States made available to the European Civil Protection Mechanism.
It is important to emphasize that for this qualitative leap and to move from information sharing and emergency response to planning and monitoring, these latter roles are crucial.

the coordination we hope for, the fundamental role of services such as GMS, and I take this opportunity to also express the concern regarding what is happening with the budget for these new technologies, which are essential.
We have emphasized the importance of communicating with citizens, as this is something the Japanese experience has taught us very well; it is never sufficient and never enough.
And we await the Commission's response, to which we request that it present the proposal on civil protection in legislative form as soon as possible.
oppressed ethnic minorities, Christians forced to practice their faith in secret, priests barbarously killed while the authorities do nothing, anti-Western foreign policy—this is today's Turkey.
My party, the Northern League, has always been opposed to Turkey's entry into Europe, as it represents a potential Trojan horse for radical Islamism in our continent.
Today more than ever, we are convinced that the EU must bring an end to accession negotiations.
The intolerable threats that Turkey has directed towards Europe must receive an immediate response.
It is unacceptable for a third country to dictate to Europe what it should do.
Cyprus is a relatively new member state of the EU and undeniably has the right to assume the rotating Presidency.
Europe must send a clear signal and demonstrate its readiness to defend Cyprus by all means necessary in the face of Turkey's political and military arrogance and bullying.
Immediately suspend the accession negotiations and be prepared to also suspend trade relations.
President, we are witnessing a decisive moment for the future of the euro and, with it, for the entire European project.
To have this awareness would mean stepping away from a short-sighted logic that subordinates everything to an ideological pursuit of fiscal rigor.
We all want the accounts of the various States to be in order, and we all want to reduce indebtedness.
However, it is clear that without an intelligent investment policy capable of revitalizing the economy, there will be no chance of growth.
The only clear outcome in this scenario is that, as always, the heaviest prices will be paid by the most vulnerable social classes.
For this reason, together with the group of Socialists and Democrats, we voted against this report.
Indeed, we are proceeding in a single direction, which is one of rigor without growth—a direction that has proven to be mistaken thus far.
I greatly appreciate the work that colleague Ferrera has done on this report.
In fact, out of the package of six legislative proposals dedicated to economic governance, it is only on this one that I and my group expressed a positive vote.

We have done this because, among other things, a clause protecting social rights has been included, starting from collective bargaining, and furthermore, there is a strengthening of the Parliament's role in the adoption of delegated acts.

Thus, while it is not possible to alter the overall balance of the six-proposal package, this report undoubtedly represents a step forward in establishing, among other things, a surveillance system that respects fundamental rights.

And so, in this context, while maintaining that a vision, in our opinion, based solely on austerity policies does not yield positive results, this report certainly represents a positive note in contrast to the trend.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, Finland and the Netherlands have taken their stand in the Council for a very simple reason: Bulgaria and Romania are currently unable to ensure effective border control and are plagued by rampant corruption that involves the political class and organized crime.
It is not the populist parties and movements that think this way, but Europol in its 2010 report on organized crime.
There is no populist propaganda, but a serious security issue.

If Bulgaria were to join the Schengen area at this time, police and security agencies predict that Bulgarian borders, especially maritime ones, would become an easy target for Turkish and Eastern European crime, and Bulgaria and Romania would become a hub for human and drug trafficking.

It is natural that some Member States have significant reservations about the actual capacity of Bulgaria and Romania to ensure effective border controls against organized crime and corruption, and it is therefore absolutely natural that they have opposed their accession to Schengen.
Allowing this now means paving the way for transnational crime and creating a breach in European borders, precisely where there is immense migratory pressure from Turkey.
The most opposing reasons are many, and Europe cannot ignore them.
I therefore ask to know what the intentions of the Commission and the Council are regarding this sensitive issue, which in my opinion has so far been addressed with...
sufficiency and without taking into account the dangers that the entry of Bulgaria and Romania would entail, according to the competent bodies in matters of security and international crime.

In my view, the Commission and the Council should postpone the accession of these two countries to Schengen and only give their approval when there is reasonable certainty that the accession of Bulgaria and Romania will not have implications for the security of European citizens.

Mr. President, the crisis in Europe is entangling the issues of public budgets and private capital in a vicious circle with those of the productivity of our businesses, and the specter of recession is indeed present.
Given that the priority of SMEs is crucial, I call on the Commission to absolutely ensure, together with the Parliament, that our good principles are put into practice.
practice and that the legislative initiatives of the SBA, the Small Business Act, become concrete practice in the Member States, with a high level of effectiveness and quality.

Commissioner, one wonders what could be achieved if the directive on combating late payment were to be implemented ahead of schedule in all member states. What a significant advantage this would be for SMEs! Thus, the focus on SMEs is crucial, but we are still at the methodological level.

It is certainly right to check whether, when we legislate, we do so in the genuine interest of and in line with the needs of small and medium-sized enterprises. However, we request that you proceed with great consistency and tenacity to thoroughly create this framework of opportunities that you have outlined.
We appreciate what the Commission is doing as well, and we are ready, with the budget and other resources at our disposal, to support it.
I'll say just one word about credit.
Let's have a clear conversation with the banks, I tell you, Commissioner, because we must support small and medium-sized enterprises.
Mr. President, I have expressed my favorable vote for the text presented by Honorable Wallis.
While not prejudicing the usual avenues of access to justice, I am convinced that an alternative dispute resolution (ADR) represents a rapid and cost-effective alternative to legal proceedings.
In addition to being an effective tool for small and medium-sized enterprises, ADR can also have significant online growth for resolving minor disputes.

Through joint action with the Member States, it is therefore necessary to promote the creation of a harmonized legal framework that, by strengthening citizens' trust in the internal market, can contribute to stimulating the European economy.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the report on provisions for sectors placed on the market under the flexibility regime, for which we have expressed our favorable vote, was inspired by a measured and realistic approach that has

materialized, on the one hand, in avoiding the establishment of unrealistic and impossible-to-meet requirements, and on the other, in providing for a so-called flexibility regime that is structured through the anticipation of temporal phases and corresponding quantitative limits.

The permitted emissions scheme involves the annual release onto the market of a predetermined quota of tractors meeting specific characteristics. This approach allows for the gradual achievement of predetermined standards over time, minimizing disruption to the affected productive and industrial sectors.

Honorable Tattarella, the work accomplished has been significant and has successfully balanced the demands of the major challenges the European Union is facing during this period with the needs of environmental protection and the current economic crisis context.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the current global economic crisis, even more severe than that of 1929, has caused unsustainable imbalances in international economies over the past few years.
Trade disparities among countries, financial markets lacking common regulations, and instability in banking systems are all potential threats to financial and economic stability.
This resolution, to which I express my support, urgently emphasizes the fundamental aspect of new rules and global economic coordination.

The economy requires a global governance system, open markets, high economic and social standards, more responsible monetary policy, and stricter supervisory policies. International decision-making bodies and economic organizations must be the key actors at the center of this new approach.

Europe, in particular, needs transparent potential to reduce instabilities exacerbated by globalization, ensure far-reaching reforms aimed at promoting growth, and reduce the debt of individual states.
This is the commitment that this resolution emphasizes to all countries.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I have cast a favorable vote for the report by our honorable colleague Ms. Matera, which examines the situation of single mothers, who today, as has already been mentioned, represent more than five percent of the population of the European Union.

The European Union therefore has a moral obligation to protect them, and the text adopted today supports those policies that can provide concrete help for these women, such as facilitations for their daily lives.
healthcare assistance, flexible work opportunities that allow for a balance between private and professional life, priority access to affordable housing, and special unemployment subsidies.
Only through the implementation of these measures can we address the needs of a category that is increasingly significant in all advanced and industrialized countries.
Thank you, President. The budget sets a few clear and important objectives within the framework of the EU 2020 strategy. For this, thanks to the rapporteurs.
It is crucial to focus on investments and not solely on the prudent maintenance of the budget.
The alternative would be to passively witness the speculative philosophy that characterizes our time.
We can no longer afford to pursue individual interests, but must finally represent a single, unified entity ready for dialogue.

I congratulate the commitments made on pilot projects and preparatory actions in heading two, as well as the funding for the integrated maritime policy not being to the detriment of other initiatives and programs in the fisheries sector.

This will enable us to implement new policies for better management of marine resources through comprehensive research and data exchange on fish stocks, introducing new approaches that can be used as best practices in other marine areas, starting from the Adriatic.

I conclude with a brief note. In the context of future debates on the CFP, and in particular regarding the Fishery Fund, I hope that greater efforts will be made towards fisheries control, which is at the heart of the fight against illegal fishing, but also forms the basis for the reconstruction of the United States.
consider the fish a common good.
Mr. President, the economic, financial, and social crisis we are going through has clearly highlighted several weak points in the European economic and social model.

I believe that one of the most representative and alarming figures of the current situation is the nearly six million jobs lost in the last three years. These numbers, given the persistence of this situation, are set to increase if there is no swift and effective response.

The text by colleague Bastos emphasizes that in order to make tangible progress, there is a need for improved energy, better synergy between education, training, and the labor market, coupled with policies aimed at ensuring greater alignment between the demand and supply of this market.
For these reasons, Mr. President, I have cast my vote in favor.
I cast a favorable vote for what was presented by Hon. Angelilli, as it addresses an issue that, as a mother and grandmother, I deeply care about.
Protecting children from sexual exploitation, abuse, and the revolting world of child pornography means safeguarding our sons and daughters, and consequently, defending the most vulnerable.
Enhanced prevention, stricter criminal penalties for perpetrators of such crimes, and more vigilant protection of children are the key points of the document voted on today.
Undoubtedly, the path is difficult.
I think in particular about the spread of child pornography via the internet, which can only be combated through close cooperation between Member States, law enforcement authorities, and providers.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the challenges posed by modernity and the report of our colleague Santa Fidina, for which we have expressed our favorable vote, require us to consider the citizen in their role as a consumer outside the traditional context.

at the heart of the community debate and remind us that safeguarding its interests cannot remain merely a principle enshrined at treaty level, but must be a tangible guiding principle of European Union policies.

A protected and informed consumer, made more aware and thus able to fully utilize the tools and resources at their disposal, able to fully enjoy their rights, must be the ultimate goal of the European Union's new consumer policy strategy.

This strategy should therefore be designed as a broad, all-encompassing approach, ranging from the financial services sector to food, from child protection to advertising, and thus be able to make a significant contribution to Europe's social and environmental goals.
The online gambling sector is continually expanding, with a turnover of several billion euros and many problematic issues to address.

Therefore, I fully agree with the adoption of all measures aimed at safeguarding the integrity of sport, also through greater coordination between the Member States and the various sports federations.
Last year, together with my colleague Iacolino, we submitted an inquiry calling for a decisive intervention by the Community institutions to prevent fraud related to rigged sporting events.

to counter the possible interference of organized crime in European sport, calling, as in the text voted on today, for a common definition of sports fraud and harmonization of sanctions at European level.
For this reason, I expressed my favorable vote today.
presented today. This and the next are crucial years for the future and the unity of Europe.

The work program must therefore more fully align with this logic of extraordinary measures, which means certainly focusing activities on essential objectives, providing more tangible effectiveness to our actions, and directing investments towards those forms that can, in turn, implement our activities.

On the other hand, other private resources, but also, as the colleague said, looking to the Commission, President Barroso, if I could have your attention for a moment, looking also to the Commission playing a more active, more direct role towards the realities of some countries and the entire eurozone and the whole of Europe.

We endorse this role of the Commission. I say this also as a representative of a country that is currently changing its government, a government that is not technocratic but rather technical, demonstrating not the abdication of political forces.

of politics, but rather the generosity, and I say this as a force that was in opposition in my country, the generosity of parties ready to do what is useful for the country even without direct representation.
So, the theme of stable and equitable growth, I believe, must address the issue of business support in two key areas: access to credit and innovation.
The Commission and Europe are able to concretely achieve this.
At the very moment we recapitalize banks, helping to recapitalize them, perhaps even with public support, we must ensure that this credit flows to the real economy, above all, to the real economy.
At the moment when Horizon 2020 becomes one of the main files, we must conduct research largely focused on innovation for businesses, large or small.
The chapter on the digital agenda, which is also very important as the creation of this single market will be a great help for our society.

Policies to combat new and old poverty, unfortunately on the rise in today's Europe, in the Europe of the crisis of recent years and also of one-sided austerity policies primarily on the part of states,

financial commitments, new resources, both in the European budget, including within the financial perspectives, and in European policies, as has just been recalled from the Social Fund to the ERDF, as well as in the budgets of individual states.
And above all, on individual states, we should use the European Semester to monitor year after year, concretely, the policies that each state dedicates to this fundamental challenge.

To make the goal of reducing poverty and social exclusion for around twenty million European citizens credible, it is therefore necessary to have consistency between the substantial resources that Europe must make available, that Member States must make available, and the concrete policies that we can implement.
It is estimated that approximately two billion euros will be required between now and 2020 to achieve the goals we have set.
This is the challenge we highlight and bring to the forefront as the Budget Committee, ensuring coherence between the financial resources we make available and the policies we support.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, there are many workers in distress in our countries, the elderly, women, youth, disabled individuals, and millions of people and families brought to their knees by the crisis and speculation.
In the face of this situation, we are here to discuss plans for supporting Roma communities and housing for immigrants.
We must focus on assisting those categories that are truly in distress and providing financial and political support to the family, which is the institution upon which our society is founded.
We must support small and medium-sized enterprises stifled by the crisis, as these SMEs are the true antidote to poverty and the genuine source of wealth for our countries.
We must prioritize our best resources, not deplete them to guarantee migrants a minimum income that Europe wants to impose from above.
Enough chatter about the Roma and immigrants. Now we must prioritize the truly excluded.
If we look around carefully, we will see many of them, and it is certainly not necessary to enter a Roma camp to see them.
The European Union must direct its efforts and funds towards these excluded groups, now more than ever.

Mr. President, I have cast my vote in favor of the text on the work of the ACP Joint Commission, which, thanks to the quality of its work, has established itself as a key player in cooperation between the North and South of the world.
I myself, as a member of said assembly, participated in the meetings held in Brussels and the works carried out in Tenerife in April 2010 and in Kinshasa, Congo, in December of the same year.

It is precisely through these visits that I have been able to personally witness, as I did in Angola in 2009, the sad conditions experienced daily by certain peoples, while also assessing the efforts made by the ACP to improve the situation.

In conclusion, I therefore feel compelled to emphasize, especially in this particular historical-political moment, notably for the countries of North Africa and the Middle East, how the role played by the CP has been one of...

Fundamental importance, especially in the context of supervising negotiations for economic partnership agreements, promoting the transparency of these processes and the development of disadvantaged local communities.
Mr. President, Honorable Zanicki, personally, I find the establishment of a European heritage brand to be an interesting concept.

At a time when, due to the persistent economic crisis, a certain euroskepticism is rising in many Member States, I believe that an initiative of this kind can strengthen the sense of belonging of European citizens to the Union.

The defining element of the European brand is not, in fact, the beauty of a site, but the symbolic value it has represented or represents for the integration of European citizens in their journey towards improved intercultural dialogue.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, in December 2009, I participated in the 15th Conference of the Parties (COP) in Copenhagen as an official member of the European Parliament's delegation.

Approximately two years have passed, and with regret, I can say that the work done and the commitments made in Copenhagen, later formalized in Cancun, will not be sufficient to achieve the goal of limiting the increase in the annual average temperature of our planet to two degrees Celsius.
Some major emitting countries, such as Japan or Russia, appear to be backing away from their commitments, while others seem to not prioritize the issue of climate change adequately.

Today, while expressing my favorable vote, I am aware that only with the great and firm will of the heads of state and governments around the world can we create the premises for a comprehensive international agreement.
Internet-related services still have great potential, both for the economy and for a more participatory and inclusive society.
Today, in the phase of transposition of the Telecom package, there is a risk, within national legislations, of fragmentation of the European framework.

Thus, the monitoring role of the Commission will be important, and I would also say the role of BEREC, which some of us would have liked to see strengthened even in the definition of the telecoms package.

The priorities we wish to emphasize in this debate are ensuring network neutrality, developing broadband infrastructure and fostering more open software, securing access and interoperability of systems, and promoting the use of...

digital technologies in various industrial sectors of services, digital content production and new services, inclusion of currently excluded individuals, I think of the disabled but not only them, defense of informational and cultural pluralism.

It must also be ensured that operators cannot impose blocks, restrictions, or discrimination on users, and that they maintain the utmost transparency in their commercial offers and all their activities.

Mr. President, all of us are aware of how important the role played by the International Criminal Court is, which deals with prosecuting the perpetrators of war crimes, crimes against humanity, and genocide.
Unfortunately, in recent times, the Court has increasingly become the target of unjust political attacks.
Its arrest warrants have often been ignored, and for this reason the current budget is not proportional to the efforts and commitment exerted.

I therefore expressed my vote in favor of the text approved today because it is the task of the European Union to take all political, diplomatic, and logistical actions to support the Court and ensure its independence and proper and effective functioning.
Thank you, President. Phosphates present in domestic washing machine detergents end up in water systems, rivers, streams, and European lakes.

Phosphorus causes an acceleration in the reproduction of various forms of life, consequently, algae and other rapidly developing plant species proliferate excessively when there is an increase in phosphorus levels in an aquatic environment.
This excessive algae growth deprives other living organisms of oxygen, can also produce toxins that destroy fish and plant species, thereby reducing the quality of the water itself.

I therefore expressed my vote in favor of the text adopted today because, in order to purify Europe's water resources, it is desirable to reduce the amount of phosphorus that is released into the waters of our continent.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the text presented by colleague Lisek analyzes possible measures to be implemented to reduce defense costs during a financial crisis that are heavily burdening the Community budget.
The main proposals focus on improved coordination of defense system planning, the pooling and sharing of defense capabilities, and support for technological research and development.
I therefore agree with the rapporteur's views that the economic and financial crisis we have been facing can provide an opportunity for integration of the
European Union defense policies, providing the impetus to develop and finally implement those ambitious reforms that have been stalled for years.
For these reasons, I have cast my vote in favor.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, a review of the European Neighborhood Policy has become necessary in the wake of the Arab Spring and the subsequent events.

It is evident that, given the current state of affairs, relations with the countries in question should be more focused on cooperation to ensure that democracy and security take priority on both sides of the Mediterranean.

In this regard, I believe that intercultural and interreligious dialogue is fundamental to strengthening mutual respect and tolerance with partner countries in the neighborhood, while at the same time promoting the fight against terrorism and extremism.
For these reasons, Mr. President, I naturally voted in favor.
Thank you, Mr. President. Yesterday in Florence, an event of extreme gravity occurred, which arouses horror and dismay.
A fifty-year-old armed man opened fire in two markets in the city of Florence, targeting five citizens of Senegalese origin. Two of them died, and three are now hospitalized in critical condition.
The murderer then committed suicide.
This is about the racist, xenophobic far-right that wanted to kill people unknown to him, guilty only of having black skin.
Florence is my city, and before being elected to the European Parliament, I served as the mayor of Florence for ten years.
Florence is a civil and democratic city, awarded the Gold Medal for its resistance against Nazism and Fascism.
Yet it was in Florence that this abominable racist crime took place, proving that Nazi-fascist madness can manifest anywhere and one must never think it has been definitively erased.

Mr. President, I ask you to express the European Parliament's condolences and to reiterate this Parliament's commitment against all forms of intolerance and for the respect and rights of every human being.
Mr. President, project management in war zones such as Afghanistan is not directly comparable to the management implemented in the countries where the project was carried out.
in developed countries or in those unaffected by conflict, with aid clearly hindered also by the stable security situation.
It is necessary, however, to try to understand the reasons for the gaps highlighted, project management and associated risk factors, in order to improve the situation as much as possible.
I share the rapporteur's view in this regard, urging the Commission to conduct a more thorough assessment of fraud, corruption, non-compliance, and the effectiveness of specific projects.
It is therefore necessary to increase the transparency and accountability of the use of Union funds and to help both Member States and other donors to avoid common mistakes.
Mr. President, we do not have the time to delve into the details or engage in high-level debate, but I believe we must acknowledge that there are some points that remain highly critical.
I share the concern over this green fund of late, where we will find the resources, remains a big question mark and a great worry.
However, I believe that to be realistic, we must acknowledge that this time in Durban, things have changed.
The outdated framework, which no longer reflected the real global geopolitical situation, has now been surpassed.
We continue to work with a picture of the world from the 1990s, an image that is now outdated, especially when we consider the perspective towards 2050. It is truly unsustainable.
We see that by 2050, among the top thirty economies in the world, there should be nineteen countries that currently still figure on the list of developing countries.
I believe that this shift in approach is perhaps the most interesting aspect from a political standpoint, and it was indeed aptly highlighted by our colleague Florence.
I also believe that we should no longer proceed in isolated compartments.

Recalling also what Mario Draghi, the Governor of the European Central Bank, said the other day in this very institution, if we also want to push in this sector towards what are the priorities, that is,

In terms of growth and employment, we truly need to be practical and focus primarily on green economy technologies to genuinely achieve sustainable development and address the most pressing needs of our citizens.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, Europe is shrinking, stocks are crashing, the centralist Europe of financial lobbies is unraveling, but the Danish Presidency opens its semester promising total loyalty to the Commission's plans for the creation of a supranational economic government of the continent.
rather than focusing on the measures to be implemented to save the destinies of 500 million citizens, the Danish government promises to act as the eurotechnocracy's faithful watchdog in the Council.
I strongly disagree with further steps.
Firstly, I fail to see how one could today propose as a priority the acceleration of the EU's enlargement process towards the Balkan countries.
There are other issues that need to be addressed promptly before concerning oneself with how to integrate the countries in Europe affected by corruption and crime.
And then Turkey, the Danish government strongly pushes for Turkey's accession.
Turkey, fortunately, is far from meeting the parameters set by the EU for entry.

But the true paradox is that, at a time when the euro is at risk, on the brink of failure, it should be the Danish Presidency that saves it, the country of Denmark, which is outside the eurozone, because it is evident that Denmark has never trusted the euro.
President, honorable colleagues, the increase in intellectual property infringements has been notable in recent years...
years risk compromising the intellectual property rights strategy in the single market launched by the Commission in May 2011.
To counter this phenomenon and safeguard the success of intellectual property protection policy, it has been proposed to entrust certain
tasks relating to the management of the European Observatory on Counterfeiting and Piracy, established in 2009 at the Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market.

This is to provide the observatory with human and financial resources suitable for undertaking actions to combat intellectual property violations and awareness-raising campaigns aimed at increasing consumer awareness of the risks associated with the purchase of counterfeit products.

The favorable vote expressed in the report thus represents a moment of great importance in the fight against the trade in counterfeit goods and in defense of innovation, growth, and the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises, as well as employment and the safety of European citizens.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, intellectual property may seem contradictory in its definition, but on the contrary, it has great moments of coherence.

I voted in favor of this proposal because its purpose, which is to entrust the European Union's trade marks, designs and models registration office with certain tasks related to the management of the European Observatory on Counterfeiting and Piracy, is necessary and indispensable in order to combat violations of intellectual property rights.

The main objectives are to raise awareness among public and private sectors about the impact of counterfeit jewelry and to inform consumers about the dangers associated with purchasing counterfeit products.
On the basis of the 33 compromise amendments, agreement was reached at first reading on December 19th.
The amendments provide that the title of the regulation and the name of the office are not to be amended in the sense of the European Observatory.
Moreover, the important and fundamental aspect is the participation of civil society in the meetings.
All this will make the moment of synthesis we are about to celebrate with today's vote even more democratic and participatory.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the report by Mr. Lechner falls within the framework of actions aimed at enhancing services for citizens and businesses within the European Union.

The interconnection of central and commercial registers is indeed an excellent tool to make communications and information retrieval more accessible and, above all, faster for citizens and businesses.
Therefore, Mr. President, I have cast my vote in favor.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, every time the situation seems to improve, new downgrades by rating agencies come to shake up the performance of international markets.
Many European companies are in crisis, and the number of people, especially the young, chronically seeking employment is rising in the job market.
If austerity measures and the defense of the euro are necessary steps, even more so are deep reforms of the labor market at the national level, aimed at revitalizing the European economy.
By reinvigorating competitiveness, we will give new confidence to investors and promote the growth of new jobs within the European Union.
Thank you, Honorable Bizzotto. I do not deny that homosexual rights need to be protected. What I deny, and this is the case in Italy, is that there are no homosexual families.

Homosexuals will never exist, simply because the family that needs to be protected, the one that the European Parliament should also protect, is the traditional family, made up of a woman, a man, and their children.
All of this seems quite elementary to me.
This is the reality in Italy and the other twenty-three countries.

Mr. President, first of all, I too would like to associate myself with the warm greeting of my colleague Lechner and also with the assessment of your work, which has been carried out with competence, tenacity, and determination.

A painstaking task, this draft regulation would sometimes get stuck, and he would bring it back to the table, starting anew with negotiations with the Council, the Commission, and the Legal Affairs Committee. I believe he can be proud of this accomplishment.
I see that there is unanimous consent in your favor.

In coming to this regulation of ours, I too am convinced that it is an important matter. Perhaps it does not make headlines in the newspapers, perhaps it is not considered high politics, but the construction of the European Union also passes through...
through satisfying the interests of citizens in their daily lives, and especially those millions and millions who, living across different states, are part of us.
They find themselves facing complex, tedious practices that sometimes touch on sensitivities at the heart of a family, which politics generally struggles to address.
The European Union should be proud to have such attention at its core.

The solutions that have been proposed are intelligent and innovative. For example, the person making the will has been given the option to choose between their usual residence or their state of origin.

And this makes the decision more flexible, given that there are such profound, truly very deep, differences between one state and another, which could constantly pose challenges for the issue of succession.
However, legal certainty has also been provided, as once the legal solution is chosen, whether it be habitual residence or country of origin, it cannot be changed.

It determines a limitation on the discretion of judges and also a limitation on the conflicts that may arise, thus providing a more peaceful way to proceed in this field. As a result, there is more freedom and greater certainty.

And then the certificate of inheritance, we believe that certificates are of little importance, this creates the conditions under which the heir has a more agile and certain position with regard to all the possible difficulties that might arise for him.
It is a fact that characterizes this law positively.

And it is true, this law is not perfect; there are issues concerning the executor, whether or not the direct inheritance is feasible, and so on. However, I do not want to say just one more word of a political nature.
We hope that the Council approves this text, we hope it becomes a regulation, but we must not seal its fate, as we cannot even contemplate the idea.
England is in a different situation with Great Britain, so, because Europe cannot do without Great Britain and therefore we should proceed to overcome these difficulties subsequently.
Thank you, sir.
Mr. President, the European Union has produced an enormous quantity of laws and regulations to construct European law and has created the European area known as the Stockholm Plan.
There is a discrepancy between this corpus, this legislative monument, and the use made of it by citizens, which is numerically and proportionally very low.
On the other hand, national judges, the legal professionals of individual states, have grown up within the legal system of their own country and have received predominant training in this regard.
meaning, whereas we believe that the true European judge is the national judge who changes their mindset and imbibes themselves with knowledge of European law.

For this reason, before discussing training, one must first address a comprehensive communication to citizens and legal professionals, so that they can become the bearers of this significant innovation and foster the willingness to utilize the benefits of this right.

But then, above all, it is a bottom-up movement that must be created in in-service training. One cannot teach as if to schoolchildren in the judicial training of adult and highly professionally qualified individuals.

One must foster curiosity in addressing one's own cases, in connecting with other colleagues, and in finding solutions, given that today common law and civil law converge, and are no longer as distant as they once were within the legal culture.

This is the real issue. In our proposals, and I am glad that the European Commission has been convinced of these aspects, we are calling for a change in approach, a bottom-up strategy, with more legal practices and less judicial training.

There is an example in the Netherlands called Eurinfra, which is very interesting. It is a network of coordinators in each court who disseminate this knowledge and encourage magistrates to engage with it.
The essence of our project is this, we hope it can have the full support of the Commission.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I would like to express, first of all, my very sincere appreciation for the work done by colleague Giegold with this initiative report. I also recall that together with him and others, we share an active presence in the social economy intergroup of this Parliament.

My political group, as you know, believes that the social model is one of the founding characteristics of the European integration project, not just one policy among many, but a policy that defines our project itself.

And in these times, with attacks also linked to the need for public spending cuts and so on, we still convincingly defend this priority. We know that it can be an updated social model, modified, but we also believe that it should be maintained, protected, and reaffirmed precisely as a priority.

Therefore, I believe that within this same vision, we must also valorize the economic entities that engage in business, that produce goods and services, such as cooperatives, which play a very specific role in the so-called European social economy.

They reiterate that production is possible, good things can be done, and efficiency can be achieved even without profit as the goal. Instead, for example, one can focus on employment, welfare, the valorization of labor, and contributing to the life of the local community.

This is why, I conclude, Mr. President, it is important for Europe to provide the necessary tools for an active policy and to create a good statute, not the current one, which is inadequate, but a good statute for cooperatives can be a way to support this crucial sector.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the role of the Cooperative Movement has always been significant in building a more balanced and fair economic dimension.
And at this moment, as we are going through one of the most severe economic and social crises since the postwar period, the function of cooperative societies becomes crucial.

there has been a robust development of the cooperative dimension in the economy, this has consequently led to an increase in employment, more qualified jobs, and a more balanced redistribution of the wealth produced.
It is therefore positive that the European Union has adopted a statute for cooperative societies, but now more than ever it is necessary that there be a real simplification of the rules.
We need to give new impetus to the creation of a common European framework in the field of cooperation, and this must be done by helping and not creating bureaucratic obstacles.
For this reason, I voted in favor of this resolution and hope that the Commission and the Council will actively work to address the issues mentioned.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the salvation of millions of unemployed Europeans does not depend on the meager assistance offered by the European Globalization Fund. The data collected highlights that most beneficiaries of the Fund are unable to find new employment, while the more fortunate are reintegrated into the labor market with fixed-term contracts of as little as six months.
In many cases, unemployed individuals give up on this fund because they doubt its usefulness.
The feico is not a solution and does not stem the disastrous consequences of a European trade policy managed dangerously and too lightly by the Commission.

To combat the scourge of unemployment, now structural in nature, Europe must curb its excessive openness to the markets of developing countries, whose unfair competition is the primary cause of the failures of our businesses.
Until Europe stops promoting economic self-harm by maintaining a short-sighted stance towards global trade flows, our businesses will continue to fail.
The fund can only provide temporary support, but it is not through training courses that our unemployed will find serenity and security.
I believe that this is a great achievement for the European Parliament today.
President Buzek, when we say we must establish an anti-Mafia committee, I recall that there were many colleagues from various countries who said, "But the Mafia is a problem of Sicily and Italy."

Today, to have been recognized by colleagues from the north of all Europe that there is a problem of organized crime in Europe and to have the will to fight together, I believe is a great and important fact, and I want to say thank you, Mr. President, and thank you to the whole Parliament.
Thank you, Mr. Sondal, for such a comprehensive presentation.

I too would like to firstly reiterate my solidarity with the families of the victims of the serious clashes that took place on December sixteenth in Zanusdaen, as well as our concern for the subsequent development of events.

What began as a union warning degenerated into the most serious incidents in which 17 people lost their lives, and in the days following the accidents, journalists and opposition representatives were arrested.

It is in the interest of all, and as Kazakhstan has also demonstrated, it is essential to shed full light on the events. I hope, therefore, that today's session will be remembered solely as a positive opportunity for our Parliament to delve deeper into what has transpired thus far.

and reiterate our call for an investigation that assures the international community that responsibilities for the events in Zanonzhen will be clarified and those responsible will be prosecuted with the utmost respect for the principles of legality and protection of human rights.

The delegation, which I have the honor of chairing, has had the opportunity, during some of its meetings, to listen to explanations provided by Kazakh authorities and also by several NGOs very active in observing events in this country.
The willingness of the Kazakhstani authorities to provide explanations, as well as their promises of further clarifications, are undoubtedly positive elements that we all should clearly appreciate.
For this reason as well, I would like to stress the need to maintain a certain balance, a balance that I had hoped to see highlighted in the text of the resolution that we will vote on tomorrow.

It would have been advisable, in my opinion, to postpone the decision until the conclusion of the official investigations, which would have benefited from the support of an official mission from international organizations.

The undeniable need to shed further light on what occurred and the requirement to urge Kazakhstan to make ever-greater efforts to improve progress towards democracy must also be constantly accompanied by a renewed commitment and an open and constructive dialogue with this country.

Mr. President, I voted in favor of this proposal as it aims to update the regulations of 2004 and 2009 to adapt to the changes in the national legislation of the Member States concerning social security and to keep pace with the evolving social realities that impact the coordination of these security systems.

This proposal also incorporates suggestions from the Administrative Commission for the Coordination of Security Systems, with the aim of improving, modernizing, and acquiring, in accordance with Article Seventy-Two, Letter F, of the previous regulation.

The amendments contained in this proposal are designed to ensure legal certainty for the parties concerned. Moreover, they aim to guarantee appropriate coordination at the European Union level of national social security systems.

It also reflects the regulatory changes at the national level and needed to be approved as it takes into account recent developments in cross-border mobility that impact the coordination of social security systems.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the credibility of the European Union at the international level and the effectiveness of its policies on human rights undoubtedly depend on the condemnation of violations, abuses, and human rights infringements.

perpetrated within or outside armed conflicts, the lack of respect for women, minors, and generally the most vulnerable, as well as persecutions based on religion or belief, but it is also of utmost importance to prevent inequality.

Mr. President, I would like to thank colleagues Asenis, Patraoneves, Romeva, and their assistants for their substantial contributions to the success of this initiative.
Fish is a common good as it provides fifteen percent of protein to over three billion people, and the livelihoods of over five hundred million people depend on fisheries and aquaculture.
This makes it a true global public good.
The approval of this statement provides the Commission with a clear direction on the necessity of promoting responsible behavior, both within fishing communities and among consumer habits.

The debate on reforming the common fisheries policy now has an additional reason to support actions that move European policy beyond the narrow focus on resource extraction methods and a set of rules that are solely inward-looking.

On the contrary, a maritime strategy is suggested as a privileged means to increase its reproductive capacity, both in inland waters and through innovative modalities of fisheries agreements with third countries.

Moreover, this is not just about environmental protection and preserving biodiversity, but also responsible fishing, economic and social sustainability, and the very interests of fishermen and our economies.
Thank you, President.
1.083/2006, presented by the European Commission in a short time, contains provisions aimed at creating a European risk-sharing instrument.

The goal is in fact to address the difficulties encountered by some Member States in raising the private financing needed for the implementation of investment projects that can only be partially funded through the use of public funds.

Although the path to exiting the economic crisis is still long, I consider the work done to reach a compromise text that set a ceiling for the funds allocated to the financial instrument and better defined the risk-sharing tools to be fruitful.
Dear colleagues, the economic crisis, technological development, and demographic changes have transformed society and the labor market in Europe in recent years.
To meet future skill demands, many people will need to complete higher education, and many workers will have to continuously add and update their skills and knowledge while already employed.

For this reason, I have expressed my favorable vote for the text of colleague Tocque, which aims at modernizing higher education systems to achieve the objectives set by the Europe 2020 strategy and promote social, cultural, and economic development within the Union.
Yes, thank you, President. I will not dwell at length, as in the limited time I would like to merely touch upon a few points.

I believe that this seventh environmental action program can certainly be a useful tool, but only if it is based on a vision of the future that takes into account the need to maintain a strong European industrial base, which is essential for maintaining a decent and acceptable level of employment.
There are things that concern me.
An absolute priority is that this program ensures the most effective implementation of already existing regulations before even setting new ones.

additional binding objectives, and I am deeply convinced that in order to address today's environmental challenges, we must rely on future environmental policies that are based on solid evidence and the most up-to-date scientific knowledge.

I am concerned about article twenty-three, which discusses the ecological footprint as an absolute indicator. It represents an indicator, an empirical model of reality, not reality itself, and we must bear this in mind.

This has many limitations; it tells us how much we impact the environment, but it absolutely does not estimate, for example, the quality of the environment. Therefore, my concerns remain, and I invite everyone to take them into account.
When we speak of good examples for citizens, when we discuss the internal market and the potential to create opportunities for growth,
authentic and tangible opportunities for change in everyday life through the internal market, we can truly use this example, we will obviously need many others, as a result of our work.
It is a good example because, as mentioned, it impacts the concrete life of citizens, their daily lives, and also helps businesses expand their market, not just because costs are high and services
reduced, but because they can increase the supply of services and, in essence, also help the economy as a whole. So, I believe it is undoubtedly a positive example, a good example.

However, you will have understood, Commissioner, that there is a widely shared will in this Parliament, I particularly refer to the contributions of two of my colleagues, Marturel Goebbels, from my group, but also many others.
others who would like this good example to become excellent and for us to move forward, in part this measure provides for this, towards a result of zero roaming, because it is possible.

No, because a European internal market entails that tariffs be similar between domestic and non-domestic entities, there is no longer a distinction when discussing a single market, and primarily because there is no technical justification for increased costs.
I remember when, in two thousand seventeen, we started talking about voice roaming, the first third-party roaming we were part of.
There was a certain incredulity and also a certain difficulty, not on the part of the Commission, I must give credit to its predecessor, Commissioner Reding.

Difficulties were widespread, coming from those who argued that the position of a true market does not foresee tariff regulation, they are political prices, belonging to an old conception of the left, and so on. There were also those who said it wouldn't work, that it would brake the market, but in the end, we did it.
