Perhaps among the many benefits, this extra-way expansion makes us realize that the possibility of use, without the fear of costs, also fosters democracy.
In Europe, there are over 120 million broadband users, with at least 70 million citizens using their mobile devices to connect to the internet, work, study, or simply stay informed.
Thanks to this regulation, the European Union has finally decided to intervene on behalf of all these consumers, reducing the cost of international telephone traffic, voice calls, data, and SMS.
A positive decision because the price reduction program will lead to an average decrease in rates of thirty-five percent over the next three years.

However, this is not enough in a challenging moment like the present one, both from an economic and an employment perspective. Communication, new technologies, and innovation are essential goods that Europe must defend with greater courage.
Every European citizen should be able to move freely between Member States, benefiting from the telephone tariff established by their national operator.

No more fraud and exorbitant bills for those traveling within the EU. If we truly want to provide a concrete response to citizens, let's create a kind of Schengen area for telecommunications, which no longer imposes different rates on citizens based on the countries in which they operate.
Mr. President, colleagues, I was part of that European Parliament delegation that visited Sicily last November.
Our delegation leader, Cecilia Wistrom, wrote a letter to the Italian minister. The interior minister's chancellor provided a response that gave us rather clear answers.

I want to recall above all the fact that after that visit to Italy the government changed, and the approach to the situation changed as well, but even the situation itself in the countries from which the migratory flow predominantly originated changed.
However, this should not divert us from the necessity of a careful analysis of what has happened and also of the current situation.

The most significant fact that remains relevant to this day is Lampedusa's status as a non-safe port, the closure of the first aid and reception center at Contrade Embriagola following the fire of the...

September 2011, which damaged it, but only partially; that is, one dormitory was destroyed and one was damaged out of seven buildings in the structure. Then, there was the de facto suppression of the project.

Now, aside from the consideration that the only unsafe port in the Mediterranean was Tripoli during Gaddafi's time, and I don't find this analogy flattering, given that migratory flows, even if significantly reduced in number, also due to seasonal reasons,

They have certainly not stopped. It is crucial that a first aid and reception operation functions effectively on Lampedusa, which is the first port of call for those arriving from the other side after journeys that are by no means easy or risk-free. This is well known by the Somali shipwreck survivors who have arrived there.

In the month of April this year, after witnessing ten people die on the overcrowded boat they were traveling on, or the twenty who were transferred from Linosa because there was no space in other reception centers, or the eighteen who still live in Linosa in the stadium's changing rooms.

And the tourist residence Cala Creta, where they are currently hosted, is certainly not a CIE (Identification and Expulsion Center) or a CARA (Reception and Assistance Center), and above all, in the meantime, both the healthcare system and the possibility of requesting asylum have been dismantled in Lampedusa.
Everything relies on the goodwill and kind-heartedness of the carabiniers on duty, or the citizens and volunteers of Lampedusa.
Another consideration to be made is the function that the center itself had assumed in the recent past.

Allowing, against every legal and ethical norm, thousands upon thousands of people to gather in a place that, due to its capacity and the function it was intended for, could only accommodate a few hundred is...

Allowing a territory of just a few square kilometers, already challenging due to its location and logistical difficulties, to be forced to accommodate a number of people greater than its own population must be addressed.
reflect on the responsibilities for an extremely tense situation that then escalated into
the fire itself.
I believe that the excellent report by colleague Rinaldi was successful in the Chamber.
I fully share the flattering assessment of the report.

Nonetheless, I would like to raise a small issue: our Europe, with respect to this new world that is seeking to find democracy and different economic conditions, is an Europe divided by the Mediterranean.

It is a particular focus on the Mediterranean that I would like the Commission to direct its attention to, both in terms of environmental aspects and in terms of the economic transactions that take place in the Mediterranean.
The Mediterranean is the fishing ground.
We are constructing a new fisheries policy in Europe that will establish very strict rules on Europe's behalf.
On the other hand, there are no rules instead.
So why not use fisheries agreement frameworks, providing support to these countries so that they can implement the same rules that are applied in Europe?

This would be beneficial for European fisheries, for the sea, for environmental conservation, to ensure that this divided region becomes less fragmented and increasingly homogeneous, thus providing a foundation for building the future of Europe and this new world.

Following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the European Parliament has become a fully-fledged institutional actor in the field of security policies and, as such, has the right to actively and determinantly participate in the priorities of the internal security strategy and the Union's security model.

The report by colleague Borsellino identifies five key sectors for which concrete actions have been proposed and calls for enhanced judicial and police cooperation among Member States to tackle organized crime and terrorism.

I believe it is of particular importance to give strong consideration to the development of prevention policies, which are a fundamental tool for ensuring a space of European freedom, security, and justice.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, with the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the foundations were laid for the development of integrated criminal law within Community law.

While upholding the importance of mutual recognition, the harmonization of protection rules, and the principle of presumption of innocence, it is crucial to emphasize that the law should be of utmost clarity and easily understandable, so as to make it clear to everyone which actions constitute a crime and which do not.
This is particularly true for directives that must be reciprocal in national law.
Any lack of clarity could indeed lead to divergent interpretations of the law.

I therefore believe that only close cooperation between European institutions on the principles and methods to be followed can ensure a coherent and high-quality European strategy in the field of criminal law.
Mr. President, the European Union safeguards the general interests of consumers against unfair business practices, misleading advertising, and abusive contractual clauses.

There is no doubt that those consumers who are more vulnerable due to age-related reasons, physical or mental health issues, or simply a lack of proper information, must be protected with greater care.
I therefore expressed my vote in favor of the text presented by colleague Perez because I agree that the creation of a strategy for consumer law is essential.
so-called most vulnerable contribute not only to their social inclusion but also to ensuring a safer, fairer, and more competitive single market.
Mr. President, the report by colleague Perez, for which we have expressed our favorable vote, focuses on the need to consider the development of a
strategy aimed at protecting the rights of the most vulnerable consumers, in view of the strategy that the European Commission and the Member States will be called upon to develop in this regard.
Consumer vulnerability arises from various causes and potentially affects everyone.

For this reason, it is necessary to provide protection for this category alongside that of the general consumer and to develop a targeted strategy in this regard, which, in considering the composite nature of the problem, avoids

on the one hand, the formulation of static and rigid definitions that are unable to consider all the nuances of the issue and the various possible forms of vulnerability, and on the other, it wards off the creation of new types of discrimination.
It is therefore necessary to arrive at the definition of specific and targeted protection measures.

Thank you, President. The management of bluefin tuna fishing has a long and rather complex history dating back to the 1990s, and to this day, it is probably the most strictly regulated by the European Union.
Despite significant investments in control measures leading to increased compliance with regulations, there are still concerns regarding the issue of overfishing.
I have therefore expressed my support for the Romeva i Rueda report, which proposes a reduction in the allowable catch rate, increased control, and strengthened capacity reduction measures.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the relations between the European Union and China clearly reveal imbalances at the commercial level.
It is therefore the duty of European institutions to strive to help European businesses emerge from the crisis and achieve fairer access to international markets.
I therefore expressed my support for this report, particularly sharing among the issues highlighted by the rapporteur the application of the principle of reciprocity to
relations between the European Union and China to allow fair competition in international markets and the demand for greater protection of intellectual property rights.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the road is still long, but today's step can be a significant one towards the long-awaited introduction and implementation of a financial transactions tax.
I understand the prudence, the caution, and the need for a gradual approach expressed by Commissioner Scemeta, as well as the technical issues rightly raised by Minister Vestager.

But for this very reason, I hope that Parliament will express a clear political will, with a large majority, to provide impetus and momentum for the initiatives needed to tackle the problems that remain unresolved, especially at Council level.
We all want to carefully assess the impact of this tax, but it is not right to stir up unfounded fears, which can also lead to contradictory and counterproductive choices.
I am referring, for example, to the logic of the proposal for exemptions.
If one is attentive to reducing the tax's impact, it is important to have the widest possible tax base, with a low rate, and not to attempt to extend exemptions indefinitely.
To those concerned about the impact on small investors, I remind them of the progressive nature of the tax, whereby those who carry out more transactions are taxed more heavily.
transactions, and it is clear that the competent authorities must in any case monitor that attempts are not made to pass on any potential costs to customers and end-users.
I therefore hope that Parliament will vote by a large majority in favor of this tax.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, since 1990, through the instrument of macro-financial assistance, the European Union has been providing economic aid in the form of grants, loans, or a combination of both to countries experiencing short-term balance of payments difficulties.
The rather lengthy timelines, combined with the difficulties posed by the decision-making criteria used so far, have made it necessary to formulate some amendments to the regulations.

I therefore welcome the proposal introduced in the new regulation, which aims to speed up and improve evaluation criteria and to agree on clearer rules and conditions for the provision of macro-financial assistance.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, there are approximately one hundred million European citizens engaged in various volunteering activities.

From major sporting events to cultural gatherings, the role played by volunteers is crucial. Equally important is the work of those who rush to offer aid and solidarity in the event of severe natural or environmental disasters.
Volunteering constitutes one of the broadest expressions of active citizenship and a crucial activity for the development of democratic values and equality within the European Union.
For this reason, I advocate the development of high-quality volunteering, both national and cross-border, and the elimination of the obstacles currently in place.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, from the communications sector to finance, transportation, energy, from culture to health, the role played by technology is becoming increasingly significant.
The increasingly frequent use of the Internet and digital tools makes the issue of cybersecurity one of the priorities on the European agenda.

Information and communication technologies can indeed promote economic and social development only if the regulations in force ensure user safety regarding data privacy and intellectual property rights.

Only through full international cooperation involving member states, institutions, and industries in the sector can a robust system be created that is capable of implementing effective measures to ensure cybersecurity.
Madam President, I thank the Commissioner; she has said very important and entirely agreeable things.
I find it truly, as he said, staggering that we have each lived in our own countries with the numbers and figures we heard earlier from colleague Oconi.
But it is equally evident that this scandal has truly highlighted the need for a thorough assessment of the European legislation currently in force on medical devices.

Unfortunately, this fraud has highlighted the gaps we have been discussing in class thus far, which the commissioner has so aptly illustrated. Therefore, I would not like to dwell on this aspect given the limited time available.
I believe it is essential to deploy all the necessary resources to ensure we can offer the best to our citizens.
But I believe that this scandal, which has taught us so many things, could also be a starting point to take a further step forward, and I build on what the colleague before me said.

The communication directed at patients is truly subpar; it always emphasizes only the positive aspects, speaking of a sort of eternal youth and promised beauty. There are no prostheses that are absolutely risk-free.

I believe that this awareness, especially when it comes to pure cosmetic surgery, should be communicated to people, to young women, because we know that there are very young girls approaching this type of procedure.
I see that you are absentmindedly agreeing, so I urge you, let's really work on this, the deadlines are tight, we should have already completed it yesterday.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the Council regulation concerning the multi-annual plan for blue whiting was adopted prior to the entry into force of the treaty, and thus an alignment has become necessary.

This regulation, the first in the fisheries sector to be aligned with the treaty, is therefore of considerable importance as the solution adopted in this case could impact the decision-making procedure applicable to other multiannual plans.
For this reason, I cast my vote in favor.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, from Seveso to Bhopal to Toulouse, there have been numerous environmental disasters in recent years that have struck Europe and endangered the health of European citizens.

Colleague Ader's text concerns the revision of the Services Directive, which aims to contain the effects of incidents involving significant quantities of dangerous and highly polluting substances released into the environment.

The revised regulations, which will come into force from June 2010, are aimed at protecting the environment and, above all, at limiting tragic health consequences for citizens. Therefore, I expressed my favorable vote.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I too would like to thank Stevenson for his excellent work and the approach he has taken in this report, which essentially addresses the two main issues.

This is not merely about a plan for managing herring; it is fundamentally about ensuring a future for fishermen in certain respects and planning for the sea to ensure that it has its protections over multiple years.
But the key point of this report is and remains the issue of delegated acts.

I believe that the Council should accept the approach set out in the Treaty of Lisbon, and I also think that it is high time for the Parliament, in some way, with a voice perhaps more authoritative than that of the European Parliament,

ensure that, whether in a debate within the Fisheries Committee or in a debate on a report concerning sprat, you have the courage to take a very clear and strong stance on the issue of delegated acts.
We claim the right for ordinary procedure to truly be in place on these matters.

I am fully aware that the issue involves, in addition to many other sectors of fishing, areas that will worsen in relation to the reform that is underway, but it concerns matters related to agriculture and other topics.
The essential aspect is respecting the will of Parliament.
In drafting this report, no account was taken of the directly concerned parties, the road haulage companies.
In Italy, ninety-one percent of freight transport takes place by road.
Their rights will be ignored if this report is approved in its current form.
In many committees of this Parliament, we work daily to reduce the financial and administrative burden on our businesses, but reports like this undermine our efforts.
all our efforts, as they will suffocate businesses themselves with new bureaucratic burdens, with ruinous economic losses, and with new forms of unfair competition.

Only a little effort would have been needed to achieve a balanced agreement, one that did not overlook the right to survival of our businesses in a very challenging economic period. However, this kind of dialogue was not possible.

On the contrary, the report deliberately ignored even previous European Union legislation, such as the 2002 directive on working time, and even ignored European Commission documents recognizing the dangers of practices such as retrofitting, which are instead proposed again in this report.
The document we will be voting on tomorrow, colleagues, will ask you to forget the positive achievements made in recent years, and once again, European businesses will bear the cost.
Just to say, Mr. President, that ACTA was a grave political mistake, setting aside the legal aspects, it elicited a massive global reaction, and that alone is enough to declare it a political error.
Why the benzene?
because it created the suspicion that access to the web was actually being closed off, which is a great modern revolution.
And why is this?
because you made the mistake of conflating counterfeiting and piracy, which are two distinctly different phenomena.
The way to combat counterfeiting has nothing to do with copyright.
And then another error that has excluded Parliament from an important activity it has been carrying out for some time, which is to create a new copyright, a new author's right.
old copyright that existed before the web. The point is that we need to work on copyright and set aside ACTA, which is an obstacle, and reject and exclude it, because it is an obstacle to our work.

Fortunately, the Commission, after months and years of hesitation, has brought two important measures—one on orphan works and the next on copyright management societies—to the attention of the Parliament.
This is the advantage. We work on this by reflecting with our brains and not just with emotion, but without red tape getting in the way.
Mr. President, I merely wish to add my voice to the praise this report has received in this Chamber regarding the need to strengthen the European Union's capacity.
to be a place where it is possible to invest, produce, and create from the perspective of our conception of an inclusive economy, socially and environmentally sustainable.

So I believe that some guidelines here are very useful in this measure, others can be added, and I think it is important to gather these suggestions and work increasingly to make attractiveness a reality.
as a consequence of territorial policies, territorial marketing, and openness, the territory proposes a productive, industrial vocation.

manufacturing and service industries that, originating from the territory, are respectful of all environmental compatibilities and at the same time align with European policies in this direction, from the territory and Europe a voice that is attractive for investments and growth.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, when discussing sensitive issues such as the authorization of products and substances for use in organic productions, we are addressing the protection of European citizens' health.

It is indeed important to meet consumer expectations regarding the quality of organic products circulating in European markets, and it is equally important to ensure the proper application of Community regulations by the authorities, bodies, and operators concerned.
For this reason, I expressed my favorable vote for the colleague's text.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, starting with the initial comments on the Council, the phase of reductive reading has now begun, and this is wrong because important steps forward have been taken.
Consider, for example, the breaking of the destructive ties between banks and public debt, the still weak plan for employment and work.

It seems that the spirit of renewal and a renewed path towards political unity is once again prevalent in European institutions, after a long period of slowness, torpor, and a desire for real progress towards greater integration.
Yesterday, we witnessed a strong unity between the Parliament and the Commission on this matter.

I am not referring to winners and losers, but it is undeniable that there has been a new institutional and political vitality compared to the past diarchy, which was the very negation, the antithesis of the communal spirit.
There was an initiative and activism by several countries not to create new excluding axes, but to build a common consensus respectful of all member states.
This is the path towards the political goal of unity, without which any banking, fiscal, and monetary union will be entirely insufficient.
On June 20th, with the Council's decision to return to member states the possibility of reinstating border controls, a new Europe was born, a brave Europe in fulfilling the desire to...
greater security for its citizens, finally inspired by a more mature interpretation of the concept of solidarity, brought back to the defense of the rights of its peoples above all.

To President Schulz, even if he is not present, I say that this historic decision does not represent an interinstitutional incident, but rather a respect for the will of the citizens, and not for that Euro-bureaucracy that has been pretending for years not to understand what is really happening outside the glass palace.
No imaginary influx of clandestines, Mr. President Schulz, but an increase in illegal immigrants, as measured by Frontex, of thirty-five percent in two thousand eleven.

I only regret that the scenes of political sterility played out in this Chamber during the last plenary session have stolen time from more useful and constructive activities. We should be asking ourselves why it was not we who defended the interests of our citizens, but the Member States.

If the Parliament does not find its own soul and the courage to stand against goodism and the sterile obviousness upon which it has been treading water for too long, it will continue to be a follower rather than a leader in the construction of the European project.
Mr. President, I wish to draw the attention of this House to the fact that yesterday, a significant event occurred...
It has been officially announced that the Higgs boson has been measured and concretely identified.
the particle that gives mass to all others and their existence, and this occurred on European soil.
Science gives life to our land, civilization, and well-being, and for a moment we can aspire to return to being a capital of world science.
Utopia is the characteristic of man who invents a utopia and wishes to bring it to fruition, and it is for science and this wonderful ambition of man that today a person
A blind person who does not have eyes can see with their hands or read a book with their ears, and a young South African boy who does not have legs can run in the Olympics in a sprint competition.
Well, Europe must be the home of science. This great event that will open new frontiers of knowledge must be fully supported by Europe.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, all too often within the European Union, crime victims do not file reports due to fear or lack of trust in institutions.
The text voted on today aims to strengthen the rights of victims of crime and to ensure them the same level of protection, assistance, and access to justice in all countries.
all the countries of the Union, paying particular attention to those victims who are at high risk of suffering further harm or intimidation during the criminal proceedings.

Of particular importance, therefore, is the recognition of victim status not only for individuals who have suffered harm as a result of a crime, but also for their family members and the deceased person as a consequence of the crime.
On September eleventh, the Catalan people peacefully demonstrated in Barcelona.
One million people demanded the independence of Catalonia from Spain.
On October fifteenth of last year, British Prime Minister Cameron signed the agreement to allow the referendum on Scotland's independence from London.
In Veneto, my region, over the past few weeks, thousands of people have signed to hold a referendum on Veneto's independence from Italy.
Yesterday, in Veneto, Lombardy, and all the northern regions, hundreds of thousands of people signed for greater autonomy from Rome.
But also in Flanders, in the Basque Country, citizens are loudly demanding autonomy and independence from the nation-states.
What does President Schulz say?
It calls for a courageous commitment to clearly say no to all separatist tendencies.
His deputy, Vidal Cuadras, went even further, advocating the use of force against Catalan citizens.
Their statements are an extremely serious act, contrary to the principles of the very democracy that we preach here and that we should defend.
I tell them that it will be the peoples who will write the future of the new Europe, not the bureaucrats of Brussels.
The path is already laid out.
The rigor policy adopted to exit the economic crisis did not yield the expected results.
As highlighted in the report by colleague Lavia, only by investing more selectively and upholding the ideal of a European budget aimed at
Supporting growth and employment will make it possible to rebalance the economies of the Member States, improving the situation of European citizens.
For this reason, I have therefore expressed my favorable vote.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the social and economic context in which the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 is being discussed is rather problematic.

With Member States committed to making fiscal adjustments to their national budgets to balance public finances, the European Union is sometimes seen as an entity that increases the financial burden on taxpayers.

For this reason, to truly overcome the crisis and ensure a better future for European youth, it will be of fundamental importance to support greater and more tangible investments in the sectors of education and development.
This is the programmatic document of an institution. From the budget, one understands what it is, what it does, and above all, what it intends to do in the future.

We are faced with a crucial choice between a survival budget, a budget of mere continuity, perhaps with everyone having a little less, or a budget of courage, of selective choices, of investments in employment, innovation, and youth—in other words, in the future of the European Union and its development vocation.

Everyone should understand that, as colleague Kalfin has stated very clearly, Europe can do today what the States can no longer do for the economy, for regional development, for the territories where social cohesion is established or destroyed, affecting the lives of the citizens we have discussed.
Major European decisions risk being suffocated today by accounting disputes within the Council, but not only, among beneficiary countries, payer countries, and paying countries.

We argue that this is a false dilemma because it is easy to demonstrate, with figures, with numbers, not with words, based on past experience, that contributing countries, sometimes more than others, benefit from economic convergence and growth.
The Council is currently working to assign figures to the various budget lines.

The war of positions has begun, with statements and stances taken by some states that view the budget as nothing more than an expense item that can be cut without remorse, indeed perhaps useful in fueling anti-European sentiment, easily exploited in times of economic crisis.
It is a mistaken position that does not aid the integration we are striving for in other areas.
Dear colleagues, our Europe is still incomplete and mutilated, many of us have said so.
We have adopted a stability pact that was also meant to be for development, but we have become so stabilized that we are in recession.
Here, let us seize at least the opportunity of this budget, of this multiannual framework, to make choices in the right direction.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the lack of information and awareness about one's rights, compounded by barriers,
Linguistic barriers and the non-recognition of diplomas and qualifications are the most common problems faced by Union citizens when residing, studying, or working in another European Union country.
Unfortunately, there is still a lack of visibility regarding the notion of European citizenship and its tangible benefits.
For this reason, I have expressed my support for 2013 as the European Year of Citizens.

The primary objective is indeed to enhance awareness of the rights associated with Union citizenship and to assist citizens in fully exercising their right to move and reside freely within the territories of the Member States.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the proliferation of innovative financial instruments presents numerous challenges in terms of regulation, governance, and monitoring their effectiveness.
Indeed, it is necessary to find a fair balance between the objectives of transparency and control, as well as a sufficient level of effectiveness and speed of implementation.

The introduction of such instruments at the European level is nevertheless of great importance, as it represents a means by which the European Union, especially in times of crisis, can stimulate investments in the economy.
in a manner aligned with its objectives, within a context where the continuous decrease in responses allocated to the community budget contrasts with the constant growth of its political ambitions.
The Brussels I Regulation has undoubtedly been one of the most effective acts
of Union legislation, as it has outlined the foundations of a European judicial space, promoting and enhancing legal certainty among European citizens.
The revision of this regulation addresses fundamental issues for the development of European justice, including the extension of rules on
on the jurisdiction over disputes involving parties domiciled in third countries and agreements regarding the choice of the competent court.

I am convinced that the adoption of the new regulation can ensure stronger consumer protection and greater legal certainty within the internal market, and for this reason, I have cast my vote in favor.

Commissioner, today you have asked Europe for a new task of coordinating industrial policies, and even the most staunch supporters of autonomy and private initiative are now calling for the exercise of this role.
Without a greater Europeanization of national strategies, also in terms of job protection, the current crisis cannot be overcome and there will be no recovery.
The automotive crisis is not merely excess production capacity; it is a dramatic loss of employment.
But the crisis now appears structural and concerns the very destiny of the automobile and the product, as we know them today.
We want to keep the automotive industry in Europe and we do not want to lose the skills, the existing know-how, and the professional expertise.
We therefore request that a major restructuring and revitalization project be initiated and implemented within a short timeframe, as costs are proportional to time.
Restructuring cannot be solely the result of fragmented national decisions or individual company initiatives.
It is necessary to at least attempt to coordinate and guide this painful process at the community level, bringing together the stakeholders through social dialogue.
producers, labor unions, and the governments of individual countries, offering support in the form of research, innovation, human capital training, retraining, and necessary funds.
I know this will be a challenging task because the national interests of individual companies are not aligned.

But since the competitive clash underway in the European Union is very ambiguous and sometimes risks being unfair, I believe that in the end it is in the interest of all countries to have an effective community impulse and guidance to jointly face the increasingly aggressive global market.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the energy crisis has exacted and continues to exact a very high price from all employment sectors, affecting thousands of precarious workers, as well as permanent and temporary employees, who are numerous in this industry.
The major steel groups are increasingly turning towards the Far East or the American continent, and this raises a big question about the direction of our development model.
I believe that Europe must reclaim the idea that a manufacturing system like ours requires robust core productions capable of supplying the European internal market.
We must therefore defend this sector and the role of a stable steel industry; we will support it, Commissioner, if we want to halt industrial decline.

I believe we need to move beyond a dualism that hasn't arisen here tonight but is often felt in discussions of this sector, a dualism between environmentalists and workers' advocates, which is mistaken because it prevents us from seeing a future perspective.
An industry that considers steelmaking as an integral part requires advanced production systems, concrete and balanced solutions that safeguard the various interests and different needs.

Therefore, a strong planning approach is needed, also at the European level, focusing on sustainability, which, in my opinion, we must not retreat from, as it represents a genuine added value with which we aim to compete globally, by supporting investments as mentioned.

It has been said from various quarters, new technologies, new processes, the upgrading of facilities for a European economy that makes effective use of resources, including energy resources, in fact starting with energy resources and also focusing on the research of new and different materials.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, as we have recalled in this Chamber, next December, the United Nations agency dedicated to communication and information technologies will meet in Dubai for the World Conference on International Communications.
The subject is the renegotiation of international telecommunications regulations.

We cannot forget, and I am pleased with Commissioner Tajani's words, the work that has been done so far, which cannot be called into question. Nor can we allow the authority of the European Union to be bypassed.

a supranational structure like the ITU, of which we know that hundreds of states from around the world are part, and many of which are known for issues related to democracy, transparency, and freedom of expression.
Therefore, it is not incorrect to believe that the pillars of the internet—that is, freedom, participation, openness, and innovation—are in danger.

Therefore, I believe it is necessary to protect the role of the Internet and, above all, the role that the Internet can play in boosting economic growth, but not only that, also to ensure opportunities for all.
I therefore hope that the Commission works towards the goal of a united Europe in Dubai, speaking with one voice.

Many are the controversial proposals presented at the negotiating table of the World Conference on International Telecommunications, in particular those that foresee changes to the governance of the Internet, which call into question network neutrality, with negative repercussions for consumers.
At risk is therefore the freedom of the Internet, or more precisely, the freedom of expression and data protection.
What some states have proposed would in fact allow a government to snoop not only on the communications of its own citizens but also on data traversing its networks.
The step from here to limiting freedom of expression to censorship is extremely short, and therefore I believe it to be in contradiction with the fundamental principles of the European Union.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I have expressed my support for the colleague's text, in particular, I agree with the rapporteur in emphasizing the fundamental role played by national judges in the application of law within the Union.

I therefore deem it necessary to fully support the efforts of the European Union aimed at improving and coordinating training on jurisdiction for judicial and administrative authorities, as well as for legal professionals.
All sector initiatives should be intensified to fully realize the concept of the Union founded on the rule of law.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, in recent years, the extraction of so-called unconventional hydrocarbons, including shale gas and oil, has brought about an unprecedented transformation in global energy markets.
Europe, in order to address this situation and reduce its dependence on hydrocarbon imports, will therefore need to rely on its potential reserves of gas and shale.
In this regard, some Member States have already authorized shale gas exploration and are preparing for the extraction phase should a discovery permit it.

In a context such as this, it becomes necessary to monitor the regulations concerning shale gas extraction within the borders of the Union in order to make the effects of its extraction more effective.
extraction, undoubtedly valid from an economic standpoint, does not create environmental problems due to the possible release of harmful substances into groundwater or the atmosphere.
Mr. President, I believe that today's occasion should be seized to speak with objectivity about Kazakhstan and the significant agreement that the country is negotiating with the European Union.
Kazakhstan is a crucial country with regard to the stability and strategic future of Central Asia, and it is undeniably an important economic and trade partner of the European Union.
This is a country that has already initiated a process of economic reforms and also a democratic process, but which still needs to commit significantly to bring these processes to full completion.

It is, however, a country that, with this goal in mind, persists in showing itself ready for new and stronger reforms, and I believe that this is precisely the task of the European Union to accompany them.

I am certain, therefore, that the signing of this enhanced agreement will allow for significant progress, as its approval will strengthen an already solid and productive relationship and ensure consistent assistance from the European Union.

I remain convinced, and I believe this should have been emphasized even more in the report we will vote on tomorrow, that the improvement of progress towards democracy and human rights must be accompanied by a renewed and open, constructive reciprocal commitment.

Our goal should not be to take a negative stance toward these and other countries due to the lack of immediate change; our goal must be to support these countries' efforts to achieve the objective of upholding human rights principles as well.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, colleagues, while thanking the rapporteurs for the reports we will vote on tomorrow, I would like to briefly address the issue of spinning and associate myself with the unanimous views expressed by all colleagues this evening.
but I wanted to focus on artisanal fishing, on the Ferrera report, which I greet and for which I congratulate him.
I wanted to say that the former Common Fisheries Policy only contributed to widening the gap between the institutions regulating fishing and its true actors, that is, the fishermen.

Unfortunately, until now in Europe, the lack of a proper definition of artisanal fishing has disadvantaged those who have always understood fishing as an activity linked to the traditions of their place, their seas, and their cuisine.

Thus, the belief grew that the course followed by the European Commission was to standardize all fishing in Europe under large-scale industrial fishing, following only market logic and not listening to the reasons of thousands of fishermen who have been practicing sustainable fishing for generations.

For decades, they have operated according to rules related to ecosystem conservation, with which I cannot but agree, but which have never preserved the work activities of the microeconomy of artisanal fishing.
This initiative report is a strong signal to the Commission, which can be translated into practical actions to the benefit of the fisheries microeconomy.
The report indeed highlights a series of advantages in allocating a minimum amount to small-scale fishing from the European Fund.

It will be necessary to encourage projects with integrated solutions that benefit the coastal community as a whole. Furthermore, Commissioner, it will be indispensable to encourage young people's access to

in this sector we have discussed it several times in the Committee because otherwise, not only will fishing likely die out due to the depletion of the seas and fish stocks, but it will also likely decline because young people are no longer entering this sector.
This report provides an opportunity to include training and incentive initiatives for young people who wish to enter the sector.
The honorable Toia now has the floor, for two minutes. As many colleagues are doing today, I ask the Council that made this proposal: but what do you intend to do, ladies and gentlemen of Europe?
Do you want to minimize it, freeze it in the future?
But it is that same Europe which then seeks to be revitalized through Van Rompuy's document on integration.
But with what coherence, I wonder, does Van Rompuy manage these two dossiers?

And what consistency can citizens find between the decisions of July, employment and growth, the lofty appeals to hope and the future in the European Union, which we also hear from the Council, and this violent fall, then, in the name of realism, into a minimal survival perspective?
How will it be possible, with these figures and these cuts, to translate the much-praised great reforms of cohesion and the CAP into concrete actions and active policies?
These are sincere questions, and we would like a clear, honest answer, because there are signs here of institutional schizophrenia that Parliament no longer accepts, that citizens no longer accept.
The Parliament seeks consistency, it demands credibility.

The first criticism is that at the budget level, we are far from anything but growth and investment; we are at the 2008 budget level. It must be acknowledged, however, that regarding heading 1, Van Rompuy's proposal reverses the scandalous Cypriot hypothesis.
It is true that here the role of the budget is recognized as an indispensable driver of growth in certain sectors, in addition to national budgets.

But let it be clear that both growth and innovation must not come at the expense of other sectors, which are also part of growth and job creation, such as cohesion policy, and also, dear colleagues, the common agricultural policy, which has increased employment and is increasingly oriented towards innovation and territorial protection.
Growing Jobs encompasses culture, training, transnational networks, the CEF, as well as solidarity and international development, human rights globally, and our contribution to the Millennium Goals.

Before us, unfortunately, is the usual spectacle of the Council: no vision, no leadership, a Babel of conflicting and competing national interests, an inextricable knot of vetoes, expectations, and general discontent.
And Europe, unfortunately, is the great absentee.
Mr. President, finning is an environmentally unacceptable practice, as it threatens the sustainability of certain shark species which depend on those very fins for their survival.

at the social and economic level, as it involves the waste of a food product with commercial value, as well as from an ethical standpoint, as it demonstrates a complete lack of respect for animal life.

Although this practice has been banned since 2003 in European waters and for the European fleet, the Commission has decided to present a proposal aimed at eliminating the exemption to the prohibition on removing shark fins on board Union fishing vessels.

This proposal, in addition to further ensuring that sharks receive the protection they need, will thus enable the European Union to actively contribute to the ongoing global effort to eradicate the cruel practice of shark finning in other parts of the world.
